Joint Antenna Selection and Beamforming for Massive MIMO-enabled Over-the-Air Federated Learning

Saba Asaad, Member IEEE, Hina Tabassum, Senior Member, Chongjun Ouyang, Member IEEE, Ping Wang, Fellow, IEEE Saba Asaad, Hina Tabassum and Ping Wang are with the Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science at York University, Toronto, Canada; emails: asaads@yorku.ca, hina.tabassum@lassonde.yorku.ca, ping.wang@lassonde.yorku.ca. Chongjun Ouyang is with the School of Information and Communication Engineering, Beijing University of Posts and Telecommunications, Beijing, China; email: dragonaim@bupt.edu.cn.
Abstract

Over-the-air federated learning (OTA-FL) is an emerging technique to reduce the computation and communication overload at the parameter server (PS) caused by the orthogonal transmissions of the model updates in conventional federated learning (FL). This reduction is achieved at the expense of introducing aggregation error that can be efficiently suppressed by means of receive beamforming via large array-antennas. This paper studies OTA-FL in massive multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) systems by considering a realistic scenario in which the edge server, despite its large antenna array, is restricted in the number of radio frequency (RF)-chains. For this setting, the beamforming for over-the-air model aggregation needs to be addressed jointly with antenna selection. This leads to an NP-hard problem due to the combinatorial nature of the optimization. We tackle this problem via two different approaches. In the first approach, we use the penalty dual decomposition (PDD) technique to develop a two-tier algorithm for joint antenna selection and beamforming. The second approach interprets the antenna selection task as a sparse recovery problem and develops two iterative joint algorithms based on the least absolute shrinkage and selection operator (Lasso) and fast iterative soft-thresholding methods. Convergence and complexity analysis is presented for all the schemes. The numerical investigations depict that the algorithms based on the sparse recovery techniques outperform the PDD-based algorithm, when the number of RF-chains at the edge server is much smaller than its array size. However, as the number of RF-chains increases, the PDD approach starts to be superior. Our simulations further depict that learning performance with all the antennas being active at the PS can be closely tracked by selecting less than 20%percent2020\% of the antennas at the PS.

Index Terms:
Over-the-air federated learning, over-the-air computation, distributed machine learning, antenna selection, radio-frequency chain, beamforming, massive MIMO.

I Introduction

Recently, federated learning (FL) has been hailed as a key distributed machine learning technique, capable of training a global model collaboratively by exchanging local model updates across clients[1]. The core idea of FL is simple: it suggests the distributed devices in the network to keep private and sensitive information on their local storage and share only the locally-trained models periodically with the parameter server (PS). The PS aggregates these local models into a global model and broadcasts it to the clients for a new local training round. This process continues until the global model parameters converge [2].

FL was originally proposed by Google to support distributed learning over wire-line connected systems [3]. The communication network was hence modeled by ideal links in the earlier research works, and the communication limits were taken into account as simple restricted budget constraints in the network [4]. Nevertheless, recent advances of intelligent wireless edge-devices and wireless technologies enable FL in wireless networks [5]. Unlike in the wire-line connected networks, wireless connections are subject to various sources of imperfection, e.g., fading channels, communication delay and (non-)linear distortion on the transmit signal, which can directly impact the training process [6]. This has led to a rich line of research work aiming to integrate the FL framework into wireless systems [7, 8, 9, 10].

The state-of-the-art techniques are mainly categorized into two streams: one that treats communication and computation separately via the transmission-then-aggregation policy [7], and the other that addresses both tasks jointly by invoking the idea of analog function computation [8, 9]. The latter approach, often referred to as over-the-air federated learning (OTA-FL), exploits the superposition applied by the wireless multiple-access channel on the input signals to realize the model aggregation directly over the air [11, 10, 12]. In this work, we focus on the latter approach that has been shown to perform more efficiently in several use cases [10]. The key idea in OTA-FL can be explained in a nutshell as follows: the edge devices transmit their local models with proper scaling simultaneously and synchronously over the same radio resource such that the desired model aggregation is determined by the linear superposition of the uplink channel. This way the devices are not required to communicate over orthogonal resources, i.e., individual bandwidth and/or time slots. OTA-FL hence offers two key advantages over the conventional approaches based on orthogonalization of the resources; first, it reduces the computational load at the PS, since the aggregation is done over the air. Second, it improves the resource efficiency, as it allows for non-orthogonal communication [13].

The mentioned gains of OTA-FL comes at the expense of noisy model aggregation, due to undesired interference and noise in the channel. Nevertheless, the aggregation error can be significantly suppressed by efficient receive beamforming using large antenna-arrays at the PS which can be realized using massive multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) systems. To this end, in this work, we focus on the highlighting the significance of massive MIMO-enabled OTA-FL in the presence of limited number of RF chains. Specifically, we design efficient joint beamforming and antenna selection methods to enhance the performance of massive MIMO-enabled OTA-FL.

I-A Related Work

It is apparent that OTA-FL scheme describes a trade-off: on one hand, it reduces the communication and computation costs by aggregating the global model directly over the air. On the other hand, unlike noise-free FL, over-the-air aggregated model is perturbed as the computation is performed on a channel that experiences fading, multi-user interference, and additive white Gaussian noise (AWGN). The calculated global model hence contains aggregation error. Consequently, the main body of work on OTA-FL addressed three key tasks: device scheduling, uplink coordination, i.e., device power control, and beamforming at the PS. The goal is to minimize the aggregation error evaluated via an error metric [11, 17, 12].

The joint design of beamforming and device scheduling policy in MIMO settings was studied in the initial work [17]. A low-complexity design based on the matching pursuit method was later proposed in [12]. A novel unit-modulus computation framework was proposed in [15] to reduce communication delay and implementation costs via analog beamforming. Low-complexity algorithms for device coordination in OTA-FL based on the minimum mean squared error (MMSE) and zero forcing (ZF) methods were proposed in [19]. The proposed algorithms present efficient approximation of the optimal MMSE and ZF schemes using a tree-based search algorithm. The problem of power control for OTA-FL was investigated in [20, 21, 22]. The study in [20] proposes a joint design for device power control and the receiver beamforming at the PS. A gradient-statistics-aware power control scheme was later introduced in [21] to accelerate the performance of OTA-FL. The study in [22] proposed truncated power control for excluding the edge devices that experience deep channel fading. The authors show that the proposed algorithm provides a good balance between learning performance and aggregation error with low-latency.

A learning-based resource allocation algorithm for enhancing the transceiver design in OTA-FL was proposed in [23]. The algorithm is trained to minimize the aggregation error accumulated over all communication rounds. Considering MIMO systems with reduced complexity, the study in [14] designs a low-complexity hybrid analog-digital beamforming scheme to establish OTA-FL in MIMO systems with large passive antenna arrays. The task-oriented design of intelligent reflecting surface (IRS)-aided MIMO systems was further investigated in [24].

I-B Motivation and Contributions

Different from the existing literature, we propose efficient beamforming and antenna selection solutions to enhance the performance of OTA-FL in massive MIMO systems. Massive MIMO provides a promising beamforming gain at the PS with considerable suppression of error in over-the-air aggregation step. This gain however relies on employing all the antennas at the server. From the implementation viewpoint, this means that each antenna should be allocated by an individual radio frequency (RF)-chain, i.e., power amplifier and analog to digital converter. This can pose a high hardware cost and complexity to the system, making it infeasible in practice. Subsequently, our motivation follows from the low-cost low-complexity approach of antenna selection that mitigates the cost and the complexity of massive MIMO-enabled OTA-FL systems[16]. To this end, our main contributions are summarized below:

  • •

    We consider a massive MIMO-enabled OTA-FL system in which a PS equipped with a large number of antennas collaboratively trains a common model via a large number of edge devices. Due to limited RF chains in practice, the PS performs antenna selection, i.e., selects a subset of its antennas and beamforming jointly.

  • •

    To tackle the design problem, we first propose an algorithm by invoking the recent penalty dual decomposition (PDD) technique developed for optimization problems with unit-modulus and/or selection constraints [26]. For the target problem, we derive the penalized and dual programming that addresses the joint antenna selection and beamforming via an unconstrained optimization. We then employ the alternating optimization (AO) method to approximate the solution of this problem within a polynomial time.

  • •

    Utilizing the sparse nature of the design given by joint antenna selection and beamforming, we develop an alternative algorithm based on sparse recovery via the Lasso. To this end, we first derive an alternative form of the original design problem that can be interpreted as the sparse recovery problem. We then invoke the Lasso algorithm along with the AO method to design a computationally-feasible algorithm for joint antenna selection and beamforming.

  • •

    Targeting applications with limited computational capacity, we develop a third class of design algorithms that impose a considerably lower computational complexity on the system. Our proposed algorithm invokes the iterative soft-threshold-based technique to bypass the linear programming task in the Lasso-based scheme. Our investigations show that the proposed approach can closely track the two other algorithms at a considerably lower complexity.

  • •

    We evaluate the efficiency of the proposed schemes through numerical simulations. We investigate the image classification problem over the FMNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets via OTA-FL with both the independent and identically distributed (i.i.d) and non-i.i.d data distributions. Our investigations depict that all the three proposed techniques outperform the classical benchmarks such as random selection, greedy antenna selection [27] and all-antenna selection. In scenarios with small number of RF-chains the Lasso-based approach can improve the test accuracy by 5 to 10 percent as compared with the PDD-based scheme at the expense of higher complexity imposed by algorithm tuning. The iterative soft-threshold-based approach, on the other hand, leads to a slightly higher aggregation error while enjoying a significantly lower computational complexity than the other two techniques.

The remainder of this paper is structured as follows. Section II introduces the problem formulation and system model. Section III proposes the PDD-based method. Sections IV and V present the Lasso and its low-complex version, i.e., FISTA algorithm, respectively. Section VI provides the simulation results and Section VII draws the conclusion.

II System Model and Problem Formulation

We consider OTA-FL in a wireless network with K𝐾K single-antenna edge devices. The devices are coordinated by a multi-antenna PS to cooperatively address a common learning task, e.g., training a neural network (NN), over their distributed local datasets using the federated averaging scheme. The PS is equipped with N𝑁N receive antenna elements. Let {1,2,⋯,K}12⋯𝐾\left\{1,2,\cdots,K\right\} denote the set of edge devices participating in the learning task. Without loss of generality, we assume that the devices are to address a supervised learning task. Each edge device has a local training dataset, denoted by 𝒟k={(𝐮k,i,vk,i)}i=1|𝒟k|subscript𝒟𝑘superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐮𝑘𝑖subscript𝑣𝑘𝑖𝑖1subscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k}=\left\{\left(\mathbf{u}_{k,i},v_{k,i}\right)\right\}_{i=1}^{|\mathcal{D}_{k}|} with 𝐮k,isubscript𝐮𝑘𝑖\mathbf{u}_{k,i} and vk,isubscript𝑣𝑘𝑖v_{k,i} representing the i𝑖i-th feature vector and its corresponding label, respectively. The global dataset is further defined as the union of all local datasets, i.e., 𝒟=∪k=1K𝒟k𝒟superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}=\cup_{k=1}^{K}\mathcal{D}_{k}. The ultimate goal in this problem is to train a learning model by minimizing the loss function F​(𝝎)𝐹𝝎F\left(\bm{\omega}\right) determined over the global dataset as

F​(𝝎|𝒟)≜∑k=1K|𝒟k||𝒟|​Fk​(𝝎|𝒟k),≜𝐹conditional𝝎𝒟superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝒟𝑘𝒟subscript𝐹𝑘conditional𝝎subscript𝒟𝑘\displaystyle F(\bm{\omega}|\mathcal{D})\triangleq\sum_{k=1}^{K}\frac{|\mathcal{D}_{k}|}{|\mathcal{D}|}F_{k}(\bm{\omega}|\mathcal{D}_{k}), (1)

where Fk​(𝝎|𝒟k)subscript𝐹𝑘conditional𝝎subscript𝒟𝑘F_{k}(\bm{\omega}|\mathcal{D}_{k}) is the local loss function determined over the local dataset of device k𝑘k as

Fk​(𝝎|𝒟k)≜1|𝒟k|​∑(𝐮k,vk)∈𝒟kℓ​(𝝎|𝐮k,vk),≜subscript𝐹𝑘conditional𝝎subscript𝒟𝑘1subscript𝒟𝑘subscriptsubscript𝐮𝑘subscript𝑣𝑘subscript𝒟𝑘ℓconditional𝝎subscript𝐮𝑘subscript𝑣𝑘\displaystyle F_{k}(\bm{\omega}|\mathcal{D}_{k})\triangleq\frac{1}{|\mathcal{D}_{k}|}\sum_{\left(\mathbf{u}_{k},v_{k}\right)\in\mathcal{D}_{k}}\ell\left(\bm{\omega}|\mathbf{u}_{k},v_{k}\right), (2)

where the sample-wise loss ℓ​(𝝎|𝐮k,vk)ℓconditional𝝎subscript𝐮𝑘subscript𝑣𝑘\ell(\bm{\omega}|\mathbf{u}_{k},v_{k}) determines the difference between the label learned by the feature vector 𝐮ksubscript𝐮𝑘\mathbf{u}_{k} and the true label vksubscript𝑣𝑘v_{k}.

For model training, the general stochastic gradient descent (SGD) method is considered. Consequently, the global model at the PS is updated by averaging the gradients of the local loss functions at model parameters of the last communication round111For ease of presentation, we assume that in each communication round we update only one epoch. This is however not necessarily the case, as in practice each communication round can include multiple local training epochs., i.e., 𝝇k​[t]=∇Fk​(𝝎​[t−1]|𝒟k)subscript𝝇𝑘delimited-[]𝑡∇subscript𝐹𝑘conditional𝝎delimited-[]𝑡1subscript𝒟𝑘\bm{\varsigma}_{k}\left[t\right]=\nabla F_{k}\left(\bm{\omega}\left[t-1\right]|\mathcal{D}_{k}\right). The updated global model is then broadcast to the participating edge devices. In this paper, we assume that the PS estimates the channel state information (CSI) accurately in the uplink channel training phase, such that the estimation error is negligible. The CSI acquisition is updated at the beginning of each channel coherence interval that is much larger than a symbol duration. In the forthcoming sections, we illustrate each stage of the OTA-FL scheme in greater detail.

II-A Over-the-Air Model Sharing

At the beginning of each communication round, the PS shares the global model 𝝎𝝎\bm{\omega} updated in the previous round with the devices. To share ςksubscript𝜍𝑘\varsigma_{k} with the PS, device k𝑘k applies a channel-dependent scaling coefficient bksubscript𝑏𝑘b_{k}. II-B Antenna Selection

The PS is equipped with L<N𝐿𝑁L<N RF-chains. It hence selects a subset of L𝐿L antenna elements in its array antenna to be active during the uplink transmission. The signal received by the PS at the digital base-band domain can hence be written as follows:

𝒚=𝐒​𝒚R=𝐒𝐇𝐁​𝝇+𝐧,𝒚𝐒subscript𝒚R𝐒𝐇𝐁𝝇𝐧\displaystyle{\bm{y}}=\mathbf{S}{\bm{y}}_{\rm R}=\mathbf{S}\mathbf{H}\mathbf{B}\bm{\varsigma}+{\mathbf{n}}, (5)

where 𝐧=𝐒𝐧R𝐧subscript𝐒𝐧R{\mathbf{n}}=\mathbf{S}{\mathbf{n}}_{\rm R} captures the AWGN process on the active antennas. II-C Over-the-Air Model Aggregation

The ultimate goal of the PS is to combine the local models according to a predefined strategy specified by the FL scheme. This means that in each uplink transmission, the PS aims to determine the aggregated model θ=∑k=1Kϕk​ςk,𝜃superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘subscript𝜍𝑘\theta=\sum_{k=1}^{K}\phi_{k}\varsigma_{k}, where θ=∇F​(𝝎)𝜃∇𝐹𝝎\theta=\nabla F(\bm{\omega}) and ϕksubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘{\phi_{k}} is a predefined weighting coefficients, i.e., ϕk=|𝒟k||𝒟|subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘subscript𝒟𝑘𝒟{\phi_{k}}=\frac{|\mathcal{D}_{k}|}{|\mathcal{D}|}. To this end, the PS invokes over-the-air computation approach and estimates the aggregated model directly from the received signal via linear beamforming, i.e., it finds the estimate of θ𝜃\theta as θ^=𝐦𝖧​𝒚^𝜃superscript𝐦𝖧𝒚\hat{\theta}={{\mathbf{m}}}^{\mathsf{H}}{\bm{y}}, for some linear receiver 𝐦∈ℂN𝐦superscriptℂ𝑁{{\mathbf{m}}}\in\mathbbmss{C}^{N}. Then, the PS updates the model parameter vector with a proper step-length γ𝛾\gamma as 𝝎t+1=𝝎t−γ​θ^superscript𝝎𝑡1superscript𝝎𝑡𝛾^𝜃\bm{\omega}^{t+1}=\bm{\omega}^{t}-\gamma\hat{\theta}.

Since communication is carried out over a noisy network, the estimated global model θ^^𝜃\hat{\mathbf{\theta}} contains some error compared to the desired global model θ𝜃\theta. This error is called aggregation error and can be quantified via various distortion metrics. In the sequel, we invoke the information-theoretic notion of mean square error (MSE) to quantify the aggregation error. Hence, the error is given by

ϵ​(𝐦,𝐬,𝐁)italic-ϵ𝐦𝐬𝐁\displaystyle\epsilon\left({\mathbf{m}},\mathbf{s},\mathbf{B}\right) =𝔼​{|θ−θ^|2}=⋆‖𝐦𝖧​𝐒𝐇𝐁−ϕ𝖧‖2+σ2​‖𝐦𝖧​𝐒‖2,absent𝔼superscript𝜃^𝜃2superscript⋆superscriptnormsuperscript𝐦𝖧𝐒𝐇𝐁superscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝖧2superscript𝜎2superscriptnormsuperscript𝐦𝖧𝐒2\displaystyle=\mathbbmss{E}\left\{|{\theta-\hat{\theta}}|^{2}\right\}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\star}}{{=}}\|{\mathbf{m}}^{\mathsf{H}}\mathbf{S}\mathbf{H}\mathbf{B}-\bm{\phi}^{\mathsf{H}}\|^{2}+\sigma^{2}\|{\mathbf{m}}^{\mathsf{H}}\mathbf{S}\|^{2}, (6)

where ϕ=[ϕ1,…,ϕK]bold-italic-ϕsubscriptitalic-ϕ1…subscriptitalic-ϕ𝐾\bm{\phi}=\left[\phi_{1},\ldots,\phi_{K}\right] and ⋆⋆\star is derived using the statistics of the local models and AWGN. As indicated in the formulation, the aggregation error is in general a function of linear receiver 𝐦𝐦{\mathbf{m}}, switching matrix 𝐒=Diag​{𝐬}𝐒Diag𝐬\mathbf{S}=\mathrm{Diag}\left\{\mathbf{s}\right\} and the transmission scaling factors 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{B}.

II-D Joint Design Problem

The main design problem is hence to find 𝐦𝐦{\mathbf{m}}, 𝐒𝐒\mathbf{S} and 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{B}, such that the aggregation error is minimized subject to the edge transmit power constraints. This main design problem of this setting is mathematically formulated as

min𝐦,𝐬,𝐁⁡ϵ​(𝐦,𝐒,𝐁)subscript𝐦𝐬𝐁italic-ϵ𝐦𝐒𝐁\displaystyle\min_{{\mathbf{m}},\mathbf{s},\mathbf{B}}\epsilon\left({\mathbf{m}},\mathbf{S},\mathbf{B}\right) (𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}_{1})
s.t.C1:𝐬∈{0,1}N,C2:𝐨N𝖳​𝐬=L,C3:|bk|2≤P​ for ​k∈[K].\displaystyle{\rm{s.t.}}\quad\begin{array}[]{l}C_{1}:\mathbf{s}\in\left\{0,1\right\}^{N},\\ C_{2}:{\mathbf{o}_{N}}^{\mathsf{T}}{\mathbf{s}}=L,\\ C_{3}:\left|b_{k}\right|^{2}\leq P\text{ for }k\in[K].\end{array} (10)

This optimization problem is in general hard to be addressed due to two main reasons: firstly, the objective function is non-convex, and secondly, the antenna selection constraint makes the problem NP-hard integer programming problem. As a result, finding the exact solution of 𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}_{1} is practically infeasible, and sub-optimal approaches for efficient approximation of the optimal design are required. In the following sections, we develop three computationally-feasible approaches based on the PDD, Lasso and soft thresholding methods. Both Lasso-type and soft-thresholding algorithms work based on sparse recovery techniques and perform well at high sparsity settings, i.e., extremely few number of antennas at the PS are active. However, with increasing the number of selected antennas at the PS the PDD approach performs superior.

III Algorithm I: A PDD-Based Method

We start with a PDD-based algorithm. This algorithm approximates the solution of 𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}_{1} by a two-tier iterative scheme that is derived by invoking the PDD method. The derivations follow three major steps:

  1. 1.

    We invoke the PDD approach to tackle the discrete nature of the antenna selection constraint, and transform 𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}_{1} to a variational form that can be effectively relaxed.

  2. 2.

    The variational problem is converted to a penalized form whose penalty is proportional to the selection constraints.

  3. 3.

    Using AO, we develop a two-tier iterative scheme to find an approximated solution of the penalized problem.

In the sequel, we go through each step in greater detail.

III-A Finding Variational Form

To drop the binary constraint of antenna selection, i.e., C2subscript𝐶2C_{2} in 𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}_{1}, PDD suggests introducing the auxiliary vector 𝐬¯=[s¯1,…,s¯N]𝖳¯𝐬superscriptsubscript¯𝑠1…subscript¯𝑠𝑁𝖳\overline{\mathbf{s}}=\left[\overline{s}_{1},\ldots,\overline{s}_{N}\right]^{\mathsf{T}} to the optimization and let its entries satisfy the following two constraints: 1. s¯n=snsubscript¯𝑠𝑛subscript𝑠𝑛{\overline{s}}_{n}=s_{n}, and 2. sn​(1−s¯n)=0subscript𝑠𝑛1subscript¯𝑠𝑛0s_{n}\left(1-{\overline{s}}_{n}\right)=0 for n∈[N]𝑛delimited-[]𝑁n\in\left[N\right]. We thus can equivalently find the solution of 𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}_{1} by solving the following optimization

min𝐬,𝐬¯,𝐁,𝐦⁡ϵ​(𝐦,𝐬,𝐁)subscript𝐬¯𝐬𝐁𝐦italic-ϵ𝐦𝐬𝐁\displaystyle\min_{\mathbf{s},\overline{\mathbf{s}},\mathbf{B},{\mathbf{m}}}\epsilon\left({\mathbf{m}},\mathbf{s},\mathbf{B}\right) (𝒫2subscript𝒫2\mathcal{P}_{2})
s.t.C1:s¯n=sn​ and ​sn​(1−s¯n)=0​ for ​n∈[N],C2:𝐨N𝖳​𝐬=L,C3:|bk|2≤P​ for ​k∈[K].\displaystyle{\rm{s.t.}}\quad\begin{array}[]{l}C_{1}:{\overline{s}}_{n}=s_{n}\text{ and }s_{n}\left(1-{\overline{s}}_{n}\right)=0\text{ for }n\in[N],\\ C_{2}:\mathbf{o}_{N}^{\mathsf{T}}\mathbf{s}=L,\\ C_{3}:\left|b_{k}\right|^{2}\leq P\text{ for }k\in[K].\end{array} (14)

This follows directly from the equivalency of the constraint C1subscript𝐶1C_{1} in the problems 𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}_{1} and 𝒫2subscript𝒫2\mathcal{P}_{2}. This equivalent form enables us to relax the antenna selection constraint more effectively.

III-B Deriving a Penalized Form

As the second step, PDD suggests transforming 𝒫2subscript𝒫2\mathcal{P}_{2} into a penalized form whose penalty includes all selection constraints, i.e., constraints C1subscript𝐶1C_{1} and C2subscript𝐶2C_{2} in 𝒫2subscript𝒫2\mathcal{P}_{2}. This penalized form is given by the augmented Lagrangian (AL) dual form of 𝒫2subscript𝒫2\mathcal{P}_{2} that is

min𝐬,𝐬¯,𝐁,𝐦⁡ϵ​(𝐦,𝐬,𝐁)+fρ​(𝐬,𝐬¯|𝝀)+hρ​(𝐬,𝐬¯|𝝁)+gρ​(𝐬,𝐬¯|β),subscript𝐬¯𝐬𝐁𝐦italic-ϵ𝐦𝐬𝐁subscript𝑓𝜌𝐬conditional¯𝐬𝝀subscriptℎ𝜌𝐬conditional¯𝐬𝝁subscript𝑔𝜌𝐬conditional¯𝐬𝛽\displaystyle\min_{\mathbf{s},\overline{\mathbf{s}},\mathbf{B},{\mathbf{m}}}\epsilon\left({\mathbf{m}},\mathbf{s},\mathbf{B}\right)+f_{\rho}\left(\mathbf{s},\overline{\mathbf{s}}|{\bm{\lambda}}\right)+h_{\rho}\left(\mathbf{s},\overline{\mathbf{s}}|\bm{\mu}\right)+g_{\rho}\left(\mathbf{s},\overline{\mathbf{s}}|\beta\right), (𝒫3subscript𝒫3\mathcal{P}_{3})
s.t.|bk|2≤P​ for ​k∈[K],\displaystyle{\rm{s.t.}}\quad\begin{array}[]{l}\left|b_{k}\right|^{2}\leq P\text{ for }k\in[K],\end{array} (16)

where the penalty terms fρ​(𝐬,𝐬¯|𝝀)subscript𝑓𝜌𝐬conditional¯𝐬𝝀f_{\rho}\left(\mathbf{s},\overline{\mathbf{s}}|{\bm{\lambda}}\right), hρ​(𝐬,𝐬¯|𝝁)subscriptℎ𝜌𝐬conditional¯𝐬𝝁h_{\rho}\left(\mathbf{s},\overline{\mathbf{s}}|\bm{\mu}\right) and gρ​(𝐬,𝐬¯|β)subscript𝑔𝜌𝐬conditional¯𝐬𝛽g_{\rho}\left(\mathbf{s},\overline{\mathbf{s}}|\beta\right) are associated to the constraints C1subscript𝐶1C_{1} and C2subscript𝐶2C_{2} in 𝒫2subscript𝒫2\mathcal{P}_{2}, respectively, and are defined as follows:

fρ​(𝐬,𝐬¯|𝝀)subscript𝑓𝜌𝐬conditional¯𝐬𝝀\displaystyle f_{\rho}\left(\mathbf{s},\overline{\mathbf{s}}|{\bm{\lambda}}\right) =12​ρ​∑n=1N[(sn−s¯n+ρ​λn)2−ρ2​λn2],absent12𝜌superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑛subscript¯𝑠𝑛𝜌subscript𝜆𝑛2superscript𝜌2superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑛2\displaystyle=\frac{1}{2\rho}\sum_{n=1}^{N}\left[\left(s_{n}-{\overline{s}}_{n}+\rho\lambda_{n}\right)^{2}-\rho^{2}\lambda_{n}^{2}\right], (17a)
hρ​(𝐬,𝐬¯|𝝁)subscriptℎ𝜌𝐬conditional¯𝐬𝝁\displaystyle h_{\rho}\left(\mathbf{s},\overline{\mathbf{s}}|\bm{\mu}\right) =12​ρ​∑n=1N[(sn​(1−s¯n)+ρ​μn)2−ρ2​μn2],absent12𝜌superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑛1subscript¯𝑠𝑛𝜌subscript𝜇𝑛2superscript𝜌2superscriptsubscript𝜇𝑛2\displaystyle=\frac{1}{2\rho}\sum_{n=1}^{N}\left[\left(s_{n}\left(1-{\overline{s}}_{n}\right)+\rho\mu_{n}\right)^{2}-\rho^{2}\mu_{n}^{2}\right], (17b)
gρ​(𝐬,𝐬¯|β)subscript𝑔𝜌𝐬conditional¯𝐬𝛽\displaystyle g_{\rho}\left(\mathbf{s},\overline{\mathbf{s}}|\beta\right) =12​ρ​[(𝐨N𝖳​𝐬−L+ρ​β)2−ρ2​β2].absent12𝜌delimited-[]superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐨𝑁𝖳𝐬𝐿𝜌𝛽2superscript𝜌2superscript𝛽2\displaystyle=\frac{1}{2\rho}\left[\left(\mathbf{o}_{N}^{\mathsf{T}}{\mathbf{s}}-L+\rho\beta\right)^{2}-\rho^{2}\beta^{2}\right]. (17c)

In these terms, ρ>0𝜌0\rho>0 is referred to as the penalty parameter. The vectors 𝝁=[μ1,…,μN]𝖳𝝁superscriptsubscript𝜇1…subscript𝜇𝑁𝖳\bm{\mu}=\left[\mu_{1},\ldots,\mu_{N}\right]^{\mathsf{T}} and 𝝀=[λ1,…,λN]𝖳𝝀superscriptsubscript𝜆1…subscript𝜆𝑁𝖳{\bm{\lambda}}=\left[\lambda_{1},\ldots,\lambda_{N}\right]^{\mathsf{T}} with μn,λn∈ℝsubscript𝜇𝑛subscript𝜆𝑛ℝ\mu_{n},\lambda_{n}\in\mathbbmss{R} in the first and second penalty, and the scalar β∈ℝ𝛽ℝ\beta\in\mathbbmss{R} in the third one being the dual variables.

In principle, the solution of (𝒫2subscript𝒫2\mathcal{P}_{2}) is found by solving the dual problem in (𝒫3subscript𝒫3\mathcal{P}_{3}) for an arbitrary ρ>0𝜌0\rho>0 and then taking the limit, when ρ𝜌\rho goes to zero [26]. PDD suggests to approximate this limit by forming an embedded double loop structure [26]: Starting with an initial penalty parameter and dual variables, the inner loop utilizes AO to solve 𝒫3subscript𝒫3\mathcal{P}_{3}. The solution is then fixed for the outer loop that iteratively updates either the dual variables or the penalty parameter depending on the constraint violation. The analyses in [26] show the convergence of this algorithm to a KKT point. In the next subsection, we derive the update rules for the inner and outer loops.

III-C Inner and Outer Loops

The algorithm iterates in a two-step manner. This means that in each iteration of the outer loop, the inner loop runs multiple iterations. We start with the inner loop assuming that the outer loop is at iteration t𝑡t. We denote the penalty parameter of this iteration with ρ(t)superscript𝜌𝑡\rho^{(t)} and the dual variables with β(t)superscript𝛽𝑡\beta^{(t)}, 𝝁(t)superscript𝝁𝑡\bm{\mu}^{(t)} and 𝝀(t)superscript𝝀𝑡{\bm{\lambda}}^{(t)}. The inner loop treats these variables as fixed and approximates the solution of 𝒫3subscript𝒫3\mathcal{P}_{3} via AO. In other words, for the given penalty parameter and dual variables of iteration t𝑡t, the inner loop minimizes the objective of 𝒫3subscript𝒫3\mathcal{P}_{3} marginally over 𝐦𝐦{\mathbf{m}}, 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{B}, 𝐬¯¯𝐬\overline{\mathbf{s}} and 𝐬𝐬{\mathbf{s}} then iterates among the marginal solutions until it converges. The marginal problems of 𝒫3subscript𝒫3\mathcal{P}_{3} describe standard quadratic optimizations whose solutions can be found within polynomial time. In the sequel, we discuss these marginal problems and derive the update rules of the inner loop:

  1. 1.

    To update the linear receiver, we solve 𝒫3subscript𝒫3\mathcal{P}_{3} with respect to 𝐦𝐦{\mathbf{m}} while treating all other variables fixed. Problem 𝒫3subscript𝒫3\mathcal{P}_{3} in this case deduces to the following unconstrained optimization

    min𝐦∈ℂN⁡12​𝐦𝖧​𝐀𝐦−ℜ⁡{𝐦𝖧​𝐚},subscript𝐦superscriptℂ𝑁12superscript𝐦𝖧𝐀𝐦superscript𝐦𝖧𝐚\displaystyle\min_{{\mathbf{m}}\in\mathbbmss{C}^{N}}\frac{1}{2}{\mathbf{m}}^{\mathsf{H}}\mathbf{A}{\mathbf{m}}-\Re\left\{{\mathbf{m}}^{\mathsf{H}}{\mathbf{a}}\right\}, (18)

    where 𝐚=𝐒𝐇𝐁​ϕ𝐚𝐒𝐇𝐁bold-italic-ϕ{\mathbf{a}}=\mathbf{S}\mathbf{H}\mathbf{B}{\bm{\phi}} and 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A} is defined as 𝐀=𝐒𝐇𝐁𝐁𝖧​𝐇𝖧​𝐒𝖧+σ2​𝐒𝐒𝖧.𝐀superscript𝐒𝐇𝐁𝐁𝖧superscript𝐇𝖧superscript𝐒𝖧superscript𝜎2superscript𝐒𝐒𝖧\mathbf{A}=\mathbf{S}\mathbf{H}\mathbf{B}\mathbf{B}^{\mathsf{H}}\mathbf{H}^{\mathsf{H}}\mathbf{S}^{\mathsf{H}}+\sigma^{2}\mathbf{S}\mathbf{S}^{\mathsf{H}}. It is readily seen that 𝐀⪰0succeeds-or-equals𝐀0\mathbf{A}\succeq 0. The problem in (18) features an unconstrained quadratic program that can be solved via standard interior point methods [29]. The solution is not generally found in a closed-form, due to the fact that det𝐀𝐀\det\mathbf{A} can be zero222This follows from the fact that 𝐒𝐒\mathbf{S} is a diagonal matrix whose entries are zero and one.. The problem is however readily solved via the command quadprog in MATLAB by rewriting it in an augmented form.

  2. 2.

    The transmit scalars are updated by solving 𝒫3subscript𝒫3\mathcal{P}_{3} for 𝐁𝐁{\mathbf{B}}. This marginal problem breaks into K𝐾K parallel sub-problems with the k𝑘k-th one being

    minbk∈ℂ⁡δk2​|bk|2−ℜ⁡{bk∗​εk}​s.t.|bk|2≤P,\displaystyle\min_{b_{k}\in\mathbbmss{C}}\frac{\delta_{k}}{2}\left|b_{k}\right|^{2}-\Re\left\{b_{k}^{*}\varepsilon_{k}\right\}\;\mathop{\mathrm{s.t.}\;}\left|b_{k}\right|^{2}\leq P, (19)

    where δk=𝐡k𝖧​𝐒𝖧​𝐦𝐦𝖧​𝐒𝐡k≥0subscript𝛿𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐡𝑘𝖧superscript𝐒𝖧superscript𝐦𝐦𝖧subscript𝐒𝐡𝑘0\delta_{k}={\mathbf{h}}_{k}^{\mathsf{H}}{\mathbf{S}}^{\mathsf{H}}{\mathbf{m}}{\mathbf{m}}^{\mathsf{H}}{\mathbf{S}}{\mathbf{h}}_{k}\geq 0 and εk∈ℂsubscript𝜀𝑘ℂ\varepsilon_{k}\in{\mathbbmss{C}} is the k𝑘k-th diagonal entry of 𝐇𝖧​𝐒𝖧​𝐦​ϕ𝖧superscript𝐇𝖧superscript𝐒𝖧𝐦superscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝖧{\mathbf{H}}^{\mathsf{H}}{\mathbf{S}}^{\mathsf{H}}{\mathbf{m}}{\bm{\phi}}^{\mathsf{H}}. This is a convex quadratic optimization with a quadratic constraint. By introducing the Lagrange multiplier λ𝜆\lambda, we define the dual Lagrangian function associated as

    ℒ​(bk,λ)=δk2​|bk|2−ℜ⁡{bk∗​εk}+λ2​(|bk|2−P).ℒsubscript𝑏𝑘𝜆subscript𝛿𝑘2superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑘2superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑘subscript𝜀𝑘𝜆2superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑘2𝑃\displaystyle{\mathcal{L}}\left(b_{k},\lambda\right)=\frac{\delta_{k}}{2}\left|b_{k}\right|^{2}-\Re\left\{b_{k}^{*}\varepsilon_{k}\right\}+\frac{\lambda}{2}\left(\left|b_{k}\right|^{2}-P\right). (20)

    The first-order optimality condition for (20) with respect to bksubscript𝑏𝑘b_{k} yields δk​bk−εk+λ​bk=0subscript𝛿𝑘subscript𝑏𝑘subscript𝜀𝑘𝜆subscript𝑏𝑘0\delta_{k}b_{k}-\varepsilon_{k}+\lambda b_{k}=0. It hence follows that bk⋆=b¯k​(λ⋆)superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑘⋆subscript¯𝑏𝑘superscript𝜆⋆b_{k}^{\star}=\bar{b}_{k}\left(\lambda^{\star}\right), where b¯k​(λ)=εkδk+λ.subscript¯𝑏𝑘𝜆subscript𝜀𝑘subscript𝛿𝑘𝜆\bar{b}_{k}\left(\lambda\right)=\frac{\varepsilon_{k}}{\delta_{k}+\lambda}. The optimal Lagrange multiplier λ⋆superscript𝜆⋆\lambda^{\star} is further found, such that the complementary slackness condition of the power constraint is satisfied. In particular, if |b¯k​(0)|2≤Psuperscriptsubscript¯𝑏𝑘02𝑃\left|\bar{b}_{k}\left(0\right)\right|^{2}\leq P, then, we have λ⋆=0superscript𝜆⋆0\lambda^{\star}=0 and thus bk⋆=b¯k​(0)superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑘⋆subscript¯𝑏𝑘0b_{k}^{\star}=\bar{b}_{k}\left(0\right).     bk⋆={εkδk|εkδk|≤Pεk|εk|​Potherwise.superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑘⋆casessubscript𝜀𝑘subscript𝛿𝑘subscript𝜀𝑘subscript𝛿𝑘𝑃subscript𝜀𝑘subscript𝜀𝑘𝑃otherwise\displaystyle b_{k}^{\star}=\begin{cases}\dfrac{\displaystyle\varepsilon_{k}}{\displaystyle\delta_{k}}&\left|\dfrac{\displaystyle\varepsilon_{k}}{\displaystyle\delta_{k}}\right|\leq P\vspace*{2mm}\\ \dfrac{\displaystyle\varepsilon_{k}}{\displaystyle\left|\varepsilon_{k}\right|}\sqrt{P}&{\text{otherwise}}\end{cases}. (21)
  3. 3.

    To update the auxiliary vector 𝐬¯¯𝐬\overline{\mathbf{s}}, we solve the marginal optimization over 𝐬¯¯𝐬\overline{\mathbf{s}} while fixing the remaining variables. This is an unconstrained quadratic optimization. Similar to the second marginal problem, this optimization breaks into N𝑁N parallel sub-problems with the n𝑛n-th sub-problem being expressed as follows:

    mins¯n∈ℝ⁡A¯n2​s¯n2−C¯n​s¯n,subscriptsubscript¯𝑠𝑛ℝsubscript¯𝐴𝑛2superscriptsubscript¯𝑠𝑛2subscript¯𝐶𝑛subscript¯𝑠𝑛\min_{\overline{s}_{n}\in{\mathbbmss{R}}}\frac{\bar{A}_{n}}{2}\overline{s}_{n}^{2}-\bar{C}_{n}\overline{s}_{n}, (22)

    where A¯n=1+sn2subscript¯𝐴𝑛1superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑛2\bar{A}_{n}=1+s_{n}^{2}, and C¯n=sn2+(1+ρ(t)​μn(t))​sn+ρ(t)​λn(t).subscript¯𝐶𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑛21superscript𝜌𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜇𝑛𝑡subscript𝑠𝑛superscript𝜌𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝜆𝑡𝑛\bar{C}_{n}=s_{n}^{2}+\left(1+\rho^{(t)}\mu_{n}^{(t)}\right)s_{n}+\rho^{(t)}\lambda^{(t)}_{n}. The optimization problem in (22) is a scalar quadratic program whose optimal solution is given by s¯n⋆=C¯nA¯n.superscriptsubscript¯𝑠𝑛⋆subscript¯𝐶𝑛subscript¯𝐴𝑛{\overline{s}}_{n}^{\star}=\frac{\bar{C}_{n}}{\bar{A}_{n}}.

  4. 4.

    The selection vector 𝐬𝐬\mathbf{s} is updated by solving 𝒫3subscript𝒫3\mathcal{P}_{3} marginally in terms of 𝐬𝐬\mathbf{s}. Similar to the marginal problem of the auxiliary vector 𝐬¯¯𝐬\overline{\mathbf{s}}, this marginal problem breaks into N𝑁N parallel sub-problems, where the n𝑛n-th sub-problem is given by

    minsn∈ℝ⁡An2​sn2−Cn​sn,subscriptsubscript𝑠𝑛ℝsubscript𝐴𝑛2superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑛2subscript𝐶𝑛subscript𝑠𝑛\min_{{s}_{n}\in\mathbbmss{R}}\frac{A_{n}}{2}{s}_{n}^{2}-C_{n}{s}_{n}, (23)

    where An=[𝐐]n,nsubscript𝐴𝑛subscriptdelimited-[]𝐐𝑛𝑛A_{n}=\left[\mathbf{Q}\right]_{n,n} and Cn=un−∑n′=1,n′≠nNℜ⁡{[𝐐]n′,n​sn′}.subscript𝐶𝑛subscript𝑢𝑛superscriptsubscriptformulae-sequencesuperscript𝑛′1superscript𝑛′𝑛𝑁subscriptdelimited-[]𝐐superscript𝑛′𝑛subscript𝑠superscript𝑛′C_{n}={u_{n}}-\sum_{n^{\prime}=1,n^{\prime}\neq n}^{N}\Re\left\{\left[\mathbf{Q}\right]_{n^{\prime},n}s_{n^{\prime}}\right\}. Here, the matrix 𝐐∈ℂN×N𝐐superscriptℂ𝑁𝑁{\mathbf{Q}}\in\mathbbmss{C}^{N\times N} is defined as follows:

    𝐐=𝐌𝖧​𝐇𝐁𝐁𝖧​𝐇𝖧​𝐌+σ2​𝐌𝖧​𝐌+12​ρ(t)​(𝟏N+𝐈N)+12​ρ(t)​(𝐈N−𝐒¯)2,𝐐superscript𝐌𝖧superscript𝐇𝐁𝐁𝖧superscript𝐇𝖧𝐌superscript𝜎2superscript𝐌𝖧𝐌12superscript𝜌𝑡subscript1𝑁subscript𝐈𝑁12superscript𝜌𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐈𝑁¯𝐒2\displaystyle\mathbf{Q}=\mathbf{M}^{\mathsf{H}}{\mathbf{H}}{\mathbf{B}}{\mathbf{B}}^{\mathsf{H}}{\mathbf{H}}^{\mathsf{H}}\mathbf{M}+\sigma^{2}\mathbf{M}^{\mathsf{H}}\mathbf{M}+\frac{1}{2\rho^{(t)}}\left(\mathbf{1}_{N}+{\mathbf{I}}_{N}\right)+\frac{1}{2\rho^{(t)}}\left(\mathbf{I}_{N}-\bar{\mathbf{S}}\right)^{2}, (24)

    for 𝐌=Diag​{𝐦}𝐌Diag𝐦\mathbf{M}=\mathrm{Diag}\left\{{\mathbf{m}}\right\} and 𝐒¯=Diag​{𝐬¯}¯𝐒Diag¯𝐬\bar{\mathbf{S}}=\mathrm{Diag}\left\{\bar{\mathbf{s}}\right\}. The scalar unsubscript𝑢𝑛u_{n} further denotes the n𝑛n-th entry of 𝐮𝐮\mathbf{u} being defined as follows:

    where the vector 𝐪𝐪\mathbf{q} that is given by

    𝐪=diag​{𝐇𝐁​ϕ​𝐦𝖧}.𝐪diag𝐇𝐁bold-italic-ϕsuperscript𝐦𝖧\displaystyle{\mathbf{q}}=\mathrm{diag}\left\{{\mathbf{H}}{\mathbf{B}}{\bm{\phi}}{\mathbf{m}}^{\mathsf{H}}\right\}. (26)

    It is worth noting that 𝐐𝐐{\mathbf{Q}} is a symmetric positive definite matrix; hence its diagonal entries are positive. This means that the optimization problem (23) is a standard convex problem whose solution is given by sn⋆=CnAn.superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑛⋆subscript𝐶𝑛subscript𝐴𝑛{{s}}_{n}^{\star}=\frac{{C}_{n}}{{A}_{n}}.

The inner loop alternates among the above four steps until it converges to a joint solution (𝐦⋆,𝐁⋆,𝐬¯⋆,𝐬⋆)superscript𝐦⋆superscript𝐁⋆superscript¯𝐬⋆superscript𝐬⋆\left({\mathbf{m}}^{\star},\mathbf{B}^{\star},\bar{\mathbf{s}}^{\star},\mathbf{s}^{\star}\right) for the given penalty parameter and dual variables in outer-loop iteration t𝑡t.

We next focus on the outer loop: getting back to the connection between the problems 𝒫3subscript𝒫3\mathcal{P}_{3} and 𝒫2subscript𝒫2\mathcal{P}_{2}, the direct approach for design of the outer loop is to update the dual variables considering the dual maximization problem. Invoking the steepest descent method, this is addressed by333See also [26, Table I, Line 4].

β(t+1)superscript𝛽𝑡1\displaystyle\beta^{(t+1)} =β(t)+𝐨N𝖳​𝐬−L2​ρ(t),absentsuperscript𝛽𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐨𝑁𝖳𝐬𝐿2superscript𝜌𝑡\displaystyle=\beta^{(t)}+\frac{\mathbf{o}_{N}^{\mathsf{T}}{\mathbf{s}}-L}{2\rho^{(t)}}, (27a)
λn(t+1)superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑛𝑡1\displaystyle\lambda_{n}^{(t+1)} =λn(t)+s¯n−sn2​ρ(t),absentsuperscriptsubscript𝜆𝑛𝑡subscript¯𝑠𝑛subscript𝑠𝑛2superscript𝜌𝑡\displaystyle=\lambda_{n}^{(t)}+\frac{{\overline{s}}_{n}-s_{n}}{2\rho^{(t)}}, (27b)
μn(t+1)superscriptsubscript𝜇𝑛𝑡1\displaystyle\mu_{n}^{(t+1)} =μn(t)+sn​(1−s¯n)2​ρ(t),absentsuperscriptsubscript𝜇𝑛𝑡subscript𝑠𝑛1subscript¯𝑠𝑛2superscript𝜌𝑡\displaystyle=\mu_{n}^{(t)}+\frac{s_{n}\left(1-{\overline{s}}_{n}\right)}{2\rho^{(t)}}, (27c)

for n∈[N]𝑛delimited-[]𝑁n\in\left[N\right]. In principle, the outer loop should iterate till both the primal and dual variables converge. In this case, we need a third-level tier to take care of the limit of ρ𝜌\rho going to zero, i.e., another loop that gradually sends the penalty parameter to zero with a certain step size; see the discussions in Section III-B where we illustrated the connection between (𝒫2subscript𝒫2\mathcal{P}_{2}) and (𝒫3subscript𝒫3\mathcal{P}_{3}). PDD invokes a trick to merge these two outer tiers, i.e., the loop that updates the dual variables and the one that takes the limit of penalty parameter going to zero, into a single loop by alternatively updating both the dual variables and the penalty parameter. To this end, at the beginning of each outer iteration, we evaluate the constraint violation of the converging solution of the inner loop by determining the violation metric hℎh that is defined as

h=maxn∈[N]⁡{|𝐨N𝖳​𝐬−L|,|s¯n−sn|,|sn​(1−s¯n)|}.ℎsubscript𝑛delimited-[]𝑁superscriptsubscript𝐨𝑁𝖳𝐬𝐿subscript¯𝑠𝑛subscript𝑠𝑛subscript𝑠𝑛1subscript¯𝑠𝑛\displaystyle h=\max_{n\in\left[N\right]}\left\{|\mathbf{o}_{N}^{\mathsf{T}}{\mathbf{s}}-L|,\left|{\overline{s}}_{n}-s_{n}\right|,\left|s_{n}\left(1-{\overline{s}}_{n}\right)\right|\right\}. (28)

This metric determines the maximum absolute deviation of the solution found by the inner loop from the equality constraints C1subscript𝐶1C_{1} and C2subscript𝐶2C_{2} in the variational optimization problem 𝒫2subscript𝒫2\mathcal{P}_{2}. We then compare the violation metric with a threshold hThsubscriptℎThh_{\rm Th}:

  • •

    If the violation metric is smaller than the threshold, i.e., h<hThℎsubscriptℎThh<h_{\rm Th}, we consider the primal solution to give a good approximation and update the dual problem via (27). In this case, the penalty parameter is kept unchanged.

  • •

    If the violation metric is larger than the threshold, we skip the update of the dual variables and reduce the penalty parameter by multiplying it with a factor κ<1𝜅1\kappa<1, i.e., ρ(t+1)=κ​ρ(t)superscript𝜌𝑡1𝜅superscript𝜌𝑡\rho^{{(t+1)}}=\kappa\rho^{(t)}.

At the end of the iteration, we further set the threshold to be the reduced version of hℎh by the same factor κ𝜅\kappa, so that the violation metric converges to zero as the outer loop converges, i.e., we set hTh←κ​h←subscriptℎTh𝜅ℎh_{\rm Th}\leftarrow\kappa h. The two-tier PDD-based algorithm is summarized in Algorithm 1. Following the analysis of [26], this algorithm is guaranteed to converge to a set of stationary solutions to the problem (𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}_{1}).

IV Algorithm II: A Lasso-Type Algorithm

According to [30, 25, 31], antenna selection problem can be naturally formulated as a sparse recovery problem. In this section, we invoke this viewpoint and develop a low-complexity algorithm based on the well-known method of Lasso for sparse recovery and regression [32].

IV-A Selection via Sparse Regression

To start with the Lasso-type algorithm, we get back to the primal optimization problem 𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}_{1}. In this problem, we have two constraints:

  1. 1.

    the transmit power of each edge-device must satisfy the power constraint, and

  2. 2.

    the number of selected antennas at the PS should be L𝐿L.

The second constraint can be written in terms of the ℓ0subscriptℓ0\ell_{0}-norm of the selection vector 𝐬𝐬\mathbf{s} as ‖𝐬‖0=Lsubscriptnorm𝐬0𝐿\left\|\mathbf{s}\right\|_{0}=L. We hence can rewrite the problem 𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}_{1} as

min𝐦,𝐬,𝐁⁡ϵ​(𝐦,𝐬,𝐁)subscript𝐦𝐬𝐁italic-ϵ𝐦𝐬𝐁\displaystyle\min_{{\mathbf{m}},\mathbf{s},\mathbf{B}}\epsilon\left({\mathbf{m}},\mathbf{s},\mathbf{B}\right) (𝒫¯1subscript¯𝒫1\bar{\mathcal{P}}_{1})
s.t.C1:𝐬∈{0,1}N,C2:‖𝐬‖0=L,C3:|bk|2≤P​ for ​k∈[K].\displaystyle{\rm{s.t.}}\quad\begin{array}[]{l}C_{1}:\mathbf{s}\in\left\{0,1\right\}^{N},\\ C_{2}:\left\|\mathbf{s}\right\|_{0}=L,\\ C_{3}:\left|b_{k}\right|^{2}\leq P\text{ for }k\in[K].\end{array} (32)

Intuitively, the equality constraint C2subscript𝐶2C_{2} can be further replaced by an inequality: in fact setting ‖𝐬‖0≤Lsubscriptnorm𝐬0𝐿\left\|\mathbf{s}\right\|_{0}\leq L means that some RF-chains are set off at the PS, which can only degrade the performance of our system. In other words, we can intuitively claim that the solution to 𝒫¯1subscript¯𝒫1\bar{\mathcal{P}}_{1} is given by solving

min𝐦,𝐬,𝐁⁡ϵ​(𝐦,𝐬,𝐁)subscript𝐦𝐬𝐁italic-ϵ𝐦𝐬𝐁\displaystyle\min_{{\mathbf{m}},\mathbf{s},\mathbf{B}}\epsilon\left({\mathbf{m}},\mathbf{s},\mathbf{B}\right) (𝒫4subscript𝒫4{\mathcal{P}}_{4})
s.t.C1:𝐬∈{0,1}N,C2:‖𝐬‖0≤L,C3:|bk|2≤P​ for ​k∈[K].\displaystyle{\rm{s.t.}}\quad\begin{array}[]{l}C_{1}:\mathbf{s}\in\left\{0,1\right\}^{N},\\ C_{2}:\left\|\mathbf{s}\right\|_{0}\leq L,\\ C_{3}:\left|b_{k}\right|^{2}\leq P\text{ for }k\in[K].\end{array} (36)

This claim is shown to be valid in the following theorem.

Theorem 1.

Let 𝐬⋆superscript𝐬⋆\mathbf{s}^{\star} be a solution of the optimization problem 𝒫¯1subscriptitalic-¯𝒫1\bar{\mathcal{P}}_{1}. Define the maximum zero-forcing error of 𝐬⋆superscript𝐬⋆\mathbf{s}^{\star} to be Ezf=‖𝐦𝖧​Diag​{𝐬⋆}​𝐇𝐁−ϕ𝖧‖∞subscript𝐸zfsubscriptnormsuperscript𝐦𝖧Diagsuperscript𝐬⋆𝐇𝐁superscriptbold-ϕ𝖧E_{\rm zf}=\|{\mathbf{m}}^{\mathsf{H}}\mathrm{Diag}\left\{\mathbf{s}^{\star}\right\}\mathbf{H}\mathbf{B}-\bm{\phi}^{\mathsf{H}}\|_{\infty}. If Ezf≠0subscript𝐸zf0E_{\rm zf}\neq 0, then 𝐬⋆superscript𝐬⋆\mathbf{s}^{\star} is also a solution of the optimization problem 𝒫4subscript𝒫4{\mathcal{P}}_{4}.

Proof.

The proof follows from the fact that with a non-zero zero-forcing error, there always exists a non-zero receiving gain for a non-selected antenna which reduces the aggregation error. This concludes that there does not exist a selection vector 𝐬𝐬\mathbf{s} with ‖𝐬‖0<Lsubscriptnorm𝐬0𝐿\left\|\mathbf{s}\right\|_{0}<L that leads to a smaller error, and hence 𝒫4subscript𝒫4{\mathcal{P}}_{4} recovers the same selection vector. The details of the proof are given in Appendix A. ∎

The optimization problem in 𝒫4subscript𝒫4{\mathcal{P}}_{4} describes a sparse regression problem in which the regression error is described via the aggregation error. Following the standard regularization technique, we find the alternative regularized form of 𝒫4subscript𝒫4{\mathcal{P}}_{4} as follows:

min𝐦,𝐬,𝐁⁡ϵ​(𝐦,𝐬,𝐁)+η​‖𝐬‖0subscript𝐦𝐬𝐁italic-ϵ𝐦𝐬𝐁𝜂subscriptnorm𝐬0\displaystyle\min_{{\mathbf{m}},\mathbf{s},\mathbf{B}}\epsilon\left({\mathbf{m}},\mathbf{s},\mathbf{B}\right)+\eta\left\|\mathbf{s}\right\|_{0} (𝒫5subscript𝒫5{\mathcal{P}}_{5})
s.t.C1:𝐬∈{0,1}N,C2:|bk|2≤P​ for ​k∈[K],\displaystyle{\rm{s.t.}}\quad\begin{array}[]{l}C_{1}:\mathbf{s}\in\left\{0,1\right\}^{N},\\ C_{2}:\left|b_{k}\right|^{2}\leq P\text{ for }k\in[K],\end{array} (39)

for some regularizer η>0𝜂0\eta>0. It is readily shown that there exists some η0subscript𝜂0\eta_{0}, such that 𝒫5subscript𝒫5{\mathcal{P}}_{5} recovers the solution of 𝒫4subscript𝒫4{\mathcal{P}}_{4} at η=η0𝜂subscript𝜂0\eta=\eta_{0}.

IV-B Sparse Regression via Box-Lasso

The problem 𝒫5subscript𝒫5{\mathcal{P}}_{5} in its primitive form is a classical computational task arising in sparse recovery which leads to the nondeterministic polynomial time (NP)-hard problem of integer programming. Various sub-optimal algorithms have been proposed in the literature to address this problem in a tractable manner [33]. The most well-known approach is the Lasso technique which approximates the solution of the sparse regression problem via the convex minimization ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1}-norm relaxation [32]. In this approach, the ℓ0subscriptℓ0\ell_{0}-norm is relaxed by the convex ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1}-norm. Analyses in [32] have shown that this relaxation guarantees the recovery of a sparse solution.

The basic form of Lasso deals with an unconstrained problem, i.e., snsubscript𝑠𝑛s_{n} are on the real axis. For the constrained case, the method is further extended to the box-Lasso; see [34] and the references therein for various forms of box-Lasso and its applications. In this scheme, the constraint set is further relaxed to a convex set, referred to as box, which includes the non-convex feasible set. Considering the constrained nature of 𝒫5subscript𝒫5{\mathcal{P}}_{5}, we use the box-Lasso method to address the underlying sparse regression problem in 𝒫5subscript𝒫5{\mathcal{P}}_{5}. To this end, we relax the integer set {0,1}Nsuperscript01𝑁\left\{0,1\right\}^{N} to the convex box [0,1]Nsuperscript01𝑁\left[0,1\right]^{N}. The box-Lasso-based relaxed problem is hence given by

min𝐦,𝐬,𝐁⁡ϵ​(𝐦,𝐬,𝐁)+η​‖𝐬‖1subscript𝐦𝐬𝐁italic-ϵ𝐦𝐬𝐁𝜂subscriptnorm𝐬1\displaystyle\min_{{\mathbf{m}},\mathbf{s},\mathbf{B}}\epsilon\left({\mathbf{m}},\mathbf{s},\mathbf{B}\right)+\eta\left\|\mathbf{s}\right\|_{1} (𝒫6subscript𝒫6{\mathcal{P}}_{6})
s.t.C1:𝐬∈[0,1]N,C2:|bk|2≤P​ for ​k∈[K],\displaystyle{\rm{s.t.}}\quad\begin{array}[]{l}C_{1}:\mathbf{s}\in\left[0,1\right]^{N},\\ C_{2}:\left|b_{k}\right|^{2}\leq P\text{ for }k\in[K],\end{array} (42)

The optimization in 𝒫6subscript𝒫6{\mathcal{P}}_{6} still describes a non-convex joint optimization problem. Its advantage is however that its marginal optimizations, i.e., optimization over a single variable while treating the others as constants, are convex. This allows us to leverage the AO method and obtain an efficient sub-optimal solution to the problem.

Remark 1.

It is worth mentioning that the regularizer η𝜂\eta in 𝒫6subscript𝒫6{\mathcal{P}}_{6} is a free variable which is tuned in practice, such that the design performance is optimized. We discuss this tuning task later in greater detail throughout the numerical investigations.

IV-C Iterative Algorithm Based on AO

We next invoke the AO method to develop an iterative algorithm for approximating the solution of 𝒫6subscript𝒫6{\mathcal{P}}_{6}. For this problem, the AO method alternates among three marginal problems, i.e., marginal problems with respect to the receiver, to the transmission scalars and to the selection vector. In the sequel, we derive the solution of each marginal problem:

  1. 1.

    The marginal problem with respect to the linear receiver 𝐦𝐦{\mathbf{m}} finds the same form as the one given in Step 1 of Section III-C. The solution is hence given by solving the quadratic optimization problem in (18).

  2. 2.

    The optimization over transmit scalars breaks into K𝐾K parallel scalar optimizations with the k𝑘k-th one being described in (19) in Step 2 of Section III-C. The solution is hence given by (21).

  3. 3.

    The last marginal problem is to optimize the objective with respect to the selection vector 𝐬𝐬\mathbf{s}, while treating 𝐁𝐁{\mathbf{B}} and 𝐦𝐦{\mathbf{m}} as constants. In this case, the corresponding problem is given by

    𝐬⋆=argmin𝐬∈[0,1]Nϵ​(𝐦,𝐬,𝐁)+η​‖𝐬‖1.superscript𝐬⋆subscriptargmin𝐬superscript01𝑁italic-ϵ𝐦𝐬𝐁𝜂subscriptnorm𝐬1\displaystyle{\mathbf{s}}^{\star}=\operatorname*{argmin}_{\mathbf{s}\in\left[0,1\right]^{N}}\epsilon\left({\mathbf{m}},\mathbf{s},\mathbf{B}\right)+\eta\left\|\mathbf{s}\right\|_{1}. (43)

    By substituting the definition of the aggregation error into (43), and after some derivations, we conclude that the solution is given by solving the following box-Lasso problem

    𝐬⋆=argmin𝐬∈[0,1]N𝐬𝖧​𝐐lasso​𝐬−2​ℜ⁡{𝐬𝖧​𝐀lasso​ϕ}+η​‖𝐬‖1,superscript𝐬⋆subscriptargmin𝐬superscript01𝑁superscript𝐬𝖧subscript𝐐lasso𝐬2superscript𝐬𝖧subscript𝐀lassobold-italic-ϕ𝜂subscriptnorm𝐬1\displaystyle{\mathbf{s}}^{\star}=\operatorname*{argmin}_{\mathbf{s}\in\left[0,1\right]^{N}}\mathbf{s}^{\mathsf{H}}\mathbf{Q}_{\rm lasso}\mathbf{s}-2\Re\left\{\mathbf{s}^{\mathsf{H}}\mathbf{A}_{\rm lasso}\bm{\phi}\right\}+\eta\left\|\mathbf{s}\right\|_{1}, (44)

    where 𝐀lasso=𝐌𝐇𝐁subscript𝐀lasso𝐌𝐇𝐁\mathbf{A}_{\rm lasso}=\mathbf{M}\mathbf{H}\mathbf{B} and 𝐐lassosubscript𝐐lasso\mathbf{Q}_{\rm lasso} is defined as

    𝐐lasso=𝐌​(𝐇𝐁𝐁𝖧​𝐇𝖧)​𝐌𝖧,subscript𝐐lasso𝐌superscript𝐇𝐁𝐁𝖧superscript𝐇𝖧superscript𝐌𝖧\displaystyle\mathbf{Q}_{\rm lasso}=\mathbf{M}\left(\mathbf{H}\mathbf{B}\mathbf{B}^{\mathsf{H}}\mathbf{H}^{\mathsf{H}}\right)\mathbf{M}^{\mathsf{H}}, (45)

    for 𝐌=Diag​{𝐦}𝐌Diag𝐦\mathbf{M}=\mathrm{Diag}\left\{{\mathbf{m}}\right\}. This is a convex optimization problem and can be solved directly by means of classical convex programming toolboxes, e.g., CVX in MATLAB or CVXPY for programming in Python. Alternatively, one can develop an iterative algorithm to solve (44) with minimal computational complexity; see [33, Chapter 15] and [35] and references therein for some instances of such algorithms.

The above steps are alternated until the solution converges. If the converging solution of 𝐬𝐬\mathbf{s} contains more than L𝐿L non-zero entries, then the selection vector is set to the L𝐿L largest entries of 𝐬𝐬\mathbf{s}. The box-Lasso-type algorithm is summarized in Algorithm 2. As mentioned, to optimize the performance further, one needs to further tune the regularizer η𝜂\eta in this algorithm. This task is often performed adaptively via numerical approaches; see for instance [36]. Analytic approaches based on large-system analysis are an alternative tuning approach which can be followed in [34, 37].

V Algorithm III: An Algorithm Based on Iterative Soft-Thresholding

Various sparse recovery techniques deal with quadratic programming [33]. A classical approach for the implementation of these techniques is to approximate the solution of the optimization problem via the Gauss-Seidel method. This results in an algorithm whose complexity linearly scales with the problem dimension. In this section, we invoke this approach to develop a low-complexity algorithm for joint antenna selection and beamforming from the Lasso-based algorithm.

We start from the box-Lasso approximation of the original design problem, i.e., (𝒫6subscript𝒫6{\mathcal{P}}_{6}). Similar to Algorithm II, we address this problem via iterative AO, where in each iteration we alternate between the marginal beamforming problem in (18) and the antenna selection problem in (43). The Gauss-Seidel method suggests approximating the solution of the latter problem in a step-wise fashion: in each step, we find the optimal entry snsubscript𝑠𝑛s_{n} while treating the other entries to be fixed.

Considering the marginal problem in (43), the Gauss-Seidel method breaks the N𝑁N-dimensional optimization into N𝑁N parallel scalar box-Lasso problems with the n𝑛n-th one being

sn⋆=argmin0≤sn≤112​(sn−zn2​wn)2+η2​wn​|sn|.superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑛⋆subscriptargmin0subscript𝑠𝑛112superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑛subscript𝑧𝑛2subscript𝑤𝑛2𝜂2subscript𝑤𝑛subscript𝑠𝑛{s}_{n}^{\star}=\operatorname*{argmin}_{0\leq{s}_{n}\leq 1}\dfrac{1}{2}\left(s_{n}-\frac{z_{n}}{2w_{n}}\right)^{2}+\frac{\eta}{2w_{n}}|s_{n}|. (46)

Here, znsubscript𝑧𝑛z_{n} and wnsubscript𝑤𝑛w_{n} are described as

znsubscript𝑧𝑛\displaystyle z_{n} =|mn|2​(σ2+∑k=1K|bk|2​|hn​k|2),absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑚𝑛2superscript𝜎2superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑘2superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑛𝑘2\displaystyle=|m_{n}|^{2}\left(\sigma^{2}+\sum_{k=1}^{K}|b_{k}|^{2}|h_{nk}|^{2}\right), (47a)
wnsubscript𝑤𝑛\displaystyle w_{n} =ℜ⁡{qn2−∑n′=1,n′≠nN[𝐐lasso]n′,n​sn′},absentsubscript𝑞𝑛2superscriptsubscriptformulae-sequencesuperscript𝑛′1superscript𝑛′𝑛𝑁subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝐐lassosuperscript𝑛′𝑛subscript𝑠superscript𝑛′\displaystyle=\Re\{\frac{q_{n}}{2}-\sum_{n^{\prime}=1,n^{\prime}\neq n}^{N}[\mathbf{Q}_{\rm lasso}]_{n^{\prime},n}s_{n^{\prime}}\}, (47b)

with 𝐐lassosubscript𝐐lasso\mathbf{Q}_{\rm lasso} being defined in (45). The scalars mnsubscript𝑚𝑛m_{n} and qnsubscript𝑞𝑛q_{n} denote the n𝑛n-th entry of 𝐦𝐦\mathbf{m} and 𝐪𝐪\mathbf{q} defined in (26), respectively, and hn​ksubscriptℎ𝑛𝑘h_{nk} is the entry of 𝐇𝐇\mathbf{H} at row n𝑛n and column k𝑘k. The solution of this scalar optimization is given in a closed form as sn⋆=12​wn​TηS​(zn),superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑛⋆12subscript𝑤𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑇𝜂𝑆subscript𝑧𝑛{s}_{n}^{\star}=\dfrac{1}{2w_{n}}T_{\eta}^{S}(z_{n}), where TηS​(u)superscriptsubscript𝑇𝜂𝑆𝑢T_{\eta}^{S}\left(u\right) is the so-called soft-thresholding operator defined as

TηS​(u)={0,|x|≤ηu−η​Sgn​(u),|x|≥η.superscriptsubscript𝑇𝜂𝑆𝑢cases0𝑥𝜂𝑢𝜂Sgn𝑢𝑥𝜂\displaystyle T_{\eta}^{S}(u)=\begin{cases}0,&|x|\leq\eta\\ u-\eta\text{Sgn}(u),&|x|\geq\eta\end{cases}. (48)

Using this approximative approach, the antenna selection in each iteration of the algorithm is performed by N𝑁N simple soft-thresholding operations: in each AO iteration, the algorithm finds the new switching vector as sn(t+1)=TηS​(zn(t))/2​wn(t)superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑛𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝑇𝜂𝑆superscriptsubscript𝑧𝑛𝑡2superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑛𝑡{s}_{n}^{(t+1)}=T_{\eta}^{S}(z_{n}^{(t)})/{2w_{n}^{(t)}}, where wn(t)superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑛𝑡w_{n}^{(t)} and zn(t)superscriptsubscript𝑧𝑛𝑡z_{n}^{(t)} are determined from (47a) and (47b) by replacing 𝐦𝐦{\mathbf{m}} and 𝐬𝐬\mathbf{s} with their values in iteration t𝑡t. The final algorithm based on the AO method is summarized in Algorithm 3. We refer to this algorithm as a fast iterative soft thresholding algorithm (FISTA) as it invokes iterative soft-thresholding for antenna selection.

VI Complexity and Convergence Analysis

In this section, we first provide the complexity analysis of the proposed algorithms in previous sections and then give a short discussion on convergence of the OTA-FL Scheme.

VI-A Complexity Analysis of the Proposed Algorithms

VI-A1 PDD-based method

In general, the PDD algorithm is more complex as compared to standard step-wise approaches, as it iterates through two tiers. To derive the complexity of this algorithm analytically, let Ioutsubscript𝐼outI_{\rm{out}} and Iinsubscript𝐼inI_{\rm{in}} denote the numbers of iterations in the outer loop and the inner loop, respectively. For each loop, we can approximate the complexity of each iteration with the dominant computational task of the iteration:

  • •

    In the outer loop, the dominant computational task in each iteration is the inner loop.

  • •

    The per-iteration complexity in the inner loop is mainly composed of the complexity of updating the primal variables 𝐦𝐦{\mathbf{m}}, 𝐁𝐁{\mathbf{B}}, 𝐬¯¯𝐬\overline{\mathbf{s}} and 𝐬𝐬{\mathbf{s}}: updating 𝐦𝐦{\mathbf{m}} requires solving a quadratic program whose complexity scales with K3superscript𝐾3K^{3}. The update of 𝐁𝐁{\mathbf{B}} needs K𝐾K parallel updates each dealing with a matrix-vector multiplication of order N𝑁N. The complexity hence scales with K​N𝐾𝑁KN. Similarly, the update of 𝐬𝐬\mathbf{s} requires N𝑁N parallel updates, each evaluating a matrix-vector product of complexity order K𝐾K. The update of 𝐬𝐬\mathbf{s} hence scales with K​N𝐾𝑁KN. Finally, 𝐬¯¯𝐬\bar{\mathbf{s}} is updated through N𝑁N parallel updates of constant complexity, and its update scales linearly with N𝑁N.

Assuming that N𝑁N and K𝐾K scale proportionally, the per-iteration complexity of the inner loop can be approximated with K3superscript𝐾3K^{3}, and thus the overall complexity of Algorithm 1 scales with Iout​Iin​K3subscript𝐼outsubscript𝐼insuperscript𝐾3I_{\text{out}}I_{\text{in}}K^{3} which is cubic in system dimension for fixed numbers of iterations.

Although the computational complexity of the proposed PDD-based algorithm is feasible in practice, it is still considered to be high in many systems with limited processing capacity.

VI-A2 Complexity Analysis of Lasso-type Algorithm

The computational complexity of the box-Lasso-type algorithm depends on the algorithm adapted for solving the box-Lasso problem in (44). Though the computational complexity varies from one implementation to another, we can consider the classical implementation based on least angle regression (LARS) [38]. In this case, the computational complexity of the box-Lasso problem scales cubically with the number of devices, i.e., K3superscript𝐾3K^{3}. Noting that the first and second marginal problems scale with K3superscript𝐾3K^{3} and K​N𝐾𝑁KN, we can conclude that the per-loop computational complexity scales with K3superscript𝐾3K^{3}. Assuming IAOsubscript𝐼AOI_{\rm AO} iterations for convergence, the algorithm imposes a computational complexity of order IAO​K3subscript𝐼AOsuperscript𝐾3I_{\rm AO}K^{3} to the system, similar to the PDD-based scheme.

Considering both Algorithms I and II, we note that the quadratic programming in (18) and the box-Lasso problem in (44) are the main computational bottlenecks. In the sequel, we develop a reduced-complexity algorithm which addresses these bottlenecks by using low-complexity alternatives for these two tasks.

VI-A3 Complexity Analysis of Iterative soft Thresholding based algorithm

The direct implementation of the FISTA-based selection deals only with matrix-vector multiplications and scales with K​N𝐾𝑁KN, which is in the same order as the complexity of the marginal problem of updating 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{B}. The complexity is hence dominated by the update of 𝐦𝐦{\mathbf{m}}, i.e., K3superscript𝐾3K^{3}.

Assuming IAOsubscript𝐼AOI_{\rm AO} iterations for convergence, the algorithm imposes a computational complexity of order IAO​K3subscript𝐼AOsuperscript𝐾3I_{\rm AO}K^{3} to the system, similar to the previous schemes. Nevertheless, as the antenna selection is performed at a significantly lower complexity, the FISTA-based approach performs with a constant factor faster than the other two approaches. We discuss this point in greater detail throughout the numerical investigations.

VI-B Convergence of the OTA-FL Scheme

In this section, we discuss the convergence of the global model parameters to the optimal solution, i.e., min𝝎⁡F​(𝝎|𝒟)subscript𝝎𝐹conditional𝝎𝒟\min_{\bm{\omega}}F\left(\bm{\omega}|\mathcal{D}\right). The convergence in general depends on various aspects: 1. the analytic properties of the local loss functions, 2. the optimization algorithm used for local updates, and 3. the joint antenna selection (AS) and beamforming algorithm used for over-the-air model aggregation. Let’s assume that the sample-wise loss function in (2), i.e., ℓ​(𝝎|𝐮k,vk)ℓconditional𝝎subscript𝐮𝑘subscript𝑣𝑘\ell\left(\bm{\omega}|\mathbf{u}_{k},v_{k}\right), is continuously differentiable with respect to 𝝎𝝎\bm{\omega} and the global loss function F​(𝝎|𝒟)𝐹conditional𝝎𝒟F\left(\bm{\omega}|\mathcal{D}\right) has a minimizer 𝝎⋆superscript𝝎⋆\bm{\omega}^{\star}. Moreover, we assume that the gradient of F​(𝝎|𝒟)𝐹conditional𝝎𝒟F\left(\bm{\omega}|\mathcal{D}\right) is Lipschitz continuous for all 𝝎1,𝝎2∈ℝUsubscript𝝎1subscript𝝎2superscriptℝ𝑈\bm{\omega}_{1},\bm{\omega}_{2}\in\mathbbmss{R}^{U} and some LL​i​p>0subscript𝐿𝐿𝑖𝑝0L_{Lip}>0, i.e., ‖∇F​(𝝎1)−∇F​(𝝎2)‖≤LL​i​p​‖𝝎1−𝝎2‖norm∇𝐹subscript𝝎1∇𝐹subscript𝝎2subscript𝐿𝐿𝑖𝑝normsubscript𝝎1subscript𝝎2\left\|\nabla F\left(\bm{\omega}_{1}\right)-\nabla F\left(\bm{\omega}_{2}\right)\right\|\leq L_{Lip}\left\|\bm{\omega}_{1}-\bm{\omega}_{2}\right\| with U𝑈U denoting the number of model parameters. And the global loss is strongly convex with parameter 0<μ<LL​i​p0𝜇subscript𝐿𝐿𝑖𝑝0<\mu<L_{Lip}, i.e., for all 𝝎,𝜹∈ℝU𝝎𝜹superscriptℝ𝑈\bm{\omega},\bm{\delta}\in\mathbbmss{R}^{U}

F​(𝝎+𝜹)≥F​(𝝎)+𝜹𝖳​∇F​(𝝎)+μ2​‖𝜹‖2.𝐹𝝎𝜹𝐹𝝎superscript𝜹𝖳∇𝐹𝝎𝜇2superscriptnorm𝜹2\displaystyle F\left(\bm{\omega}+\bm{\delta}\right)\geq F\left(\bm{\omega}\right)+\bm{\delta}^{\mathsf{T}}\nabla F\left(\bm{\omega}\right)+\frac{\mu}{2}\left\|\bm{\delta}\right\|^{2}. (49)

We further assume that the edge devices use SGD to locally update their model parameters.

We now invoke the results of [39] which characterizes the so-called optimality gap of the SGD in terms of the MSE between the noisy calculation of the gradient and its true value. The optimality gap is defined to be the difference between the loss of the global model in communication round t𝑡t, i.e., F​(𝝎​[t])𝐹𝝎delimited-[]𝑡F(\bm{\omega}\left[t\right]), and the optimal solution, i.e., F​(𝝎⋆)𝐹superscript𝝎⋆F(\bm{\omega}^{\star}). Using the results of [39], we show that the optimality gap in our setting can be reduced in each iteration, and hence the FL scheme converges to a point in the vicinity of the optimal solution. To this end, let us define the optimality gap in iteration t𝑡t formally as G​[t]=𝔼​{F​(𝝎​[t])−F​(𝝎⋆)}𝐺delimited-[]𝑡𝔼𝐹𝝎delimited-[]𝑡𝐹superscript𝝎⋆G\left[t\right]=\mathbbmss{E}\left\{F(\bm{\omega}\left[t\right])-F(\bm{\omega}^{\star})\right\}. Using Lemma 2.1. in [39], we can bound the optimality gap in the next communication round as

G​[t+1]≤(1−μLL​i​p)​G​[t]+12​LL​i​p​ϵ(t)​(𝐦,𝐬,𝐁),𝐺delimited-[]𝑡11𝜇subscript𝐿𝐿𝑖𝑝𝐺delimited-[]𝑡12subscript𝐿𝐿𝑖𝑝superscriptitalic-ϵ𝑡𝐦𝐬𝐁\displaystyle G\left[t+1\right]\leq\left(1-\frac{\mu}{L_{Lip}}\right)G\left[t\right]+\frac{1}{2L_{Lip}}\epsilon^{(t)}\left({\mathbf{m}},\mathbf{s},\mathbf{B}\right), (50)

with ϵ(t)​(𝐦,𝐬,𝐁)superscriptitalic-ϵ𝑡𝐦𝐬𝐁\epsilon^{(t)}\left({\mathbf{m}},\mathbf{s},\mathbf{B}\right) denoting the aggregation error in communication round t𝑡t determined by setting the designed 𝐦𝐦{\mathbf{m}}, 𝐬𝐬\mathbf{s} and 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{B} into (6).

We now denote the aggregation error achieved by a particular algorithm in communication round t𝑡t with ϵ​[t]italic-ϵdelimited-[]𝑡\epsilon\left[t\right]. Substituting in (50), we conclude that starting from a point with large optimality gap, the OTA-FL scheme moves towards the optimal solution as long as G​[t]>ϵ​[t]2​μ𝐺delimited-[]𝑡italic-ϵdelimited-[]𝑡2𝜇G\left[t\right]>\frac{\epsilon\left[t\right]}{2\mu}. This guarantees that with enough number of communication rounds the final solution determined by the OTA-FL scheme is in the vicinity of the optimal solution. The optimality gap of the converging solution moreover depends on the joint selection and beamforming algorithm: the smaller the achieved aggregation error is, the closer to the optimal solution the algorithm converges.

VII Numerical Results and Discussions

In this section, we conduct multiple experiments to evaluate performance of the proposed algorithms. We consider a multi-user network in which a set of edge devices invoke the FL framework to learn a common model for a 10-class image classification problem.

VII-A Communication Settings

We consider a single cell of a cellular network with K=50𝐾50K=50 single-antenna edge devices and a PS that is equipped with N=128𝑁128N=128 antennas. The maximum transmit power of each edge device is set to P=1𝑃1P=1 W. The PS is located at the center of the cell and the locations of the devices are uniformly and randomly generated within a ring whose inner radius is Rin=10subscript𝑅in10R_{\mathrm{in}}=10 m and whose outer radius is Rout=100subscript𝑅out100R_{\mathrm{out}}=100 m. The vector of channel coefficients between the device k𝑘k and the PS is generated as 𝐡k=ρkL​(dk)​𝐠ksubscript𝐡𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜌𝑘𝐿subscript𝑑𝑘subscript𝐠𝑘\mathbf{h}_{k}=\sqrt{\rho_{k}^{L}(d_{k})}\mathbf{g}_{k}, where ρkLsuperscriptsubscript𝜌𝑘𝐿\rho_{k}^{L} models the large-scale path loss and 𝐠ksubscript𝐠𝑘\mathbf{g}_{k} captures the small-scale fading. The path-loss is determined from the distance from the PS as ρkL​(dk)=ρref​(dkdref)−αsuperscriptsubscript𝜌𝑘𝐿subscript𝑑𝑘subscript𝜌refsuperscriptsubscript𝑑𝑘subscript𝑑ref𝛼\rho_{k}^{L}\left(d_{k}\right)=\rho_{\mathrm{ref}}\left(\dfrac{d_{k}}{d_{\mathrm{ref}}}\right)^{-\alpha} where dksubscript𝑑𝑘d_{k} denotes the distance between device k𝑘k and the PS, α𝛼\alpha is the path loss exponent and ρrefsubscript𝜌ref\rho_{\mathrm{ref}} is the path-loss at the reference distance of drefsubscript𝑑refd_{\mathrm{ref}}.

For the fading process, we consider the Rayleigh model. This means that the entries of 𝐠ksubscript𝐠𝑘\mathbf{g}_{k} are generated i.i.d according to a complex Gaussian distribution with zero-mean and covariance matrix 𝐑ksubscript𝐑𝑘\mathbf{R}_{k}, i.e., 𝐠k∼𝒞​𝒩​(0,𝐑k)similar-tosubscript𝐠𝑘𝒞𝒩0subscript𝐑𝑘\mathbf{g}_{k}\sim\mathcal{CN}\left(0,\mathbf{R}_{k}\right). We use the Rayleigh model for correlation [40] meaning that the entries of covariance matrix 𝐑ksubscript𝐑𝑘\mathbf{R}_{k} are set to [𝐑k]n,m=un−m​(κk)​ξn,m(k)​(κk)subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝐑𝑘𝑛𝑚superscript𝑢𝑛𝑚subscript𝜅𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑛𝑚𝑘subscript𝜅𝑘{\left[\mathbf{R}_{k}\right]}_{n,m}=u^{n-m}\left(\kappa_{k}\right)\xi_{n,m}^{(k)}\left(\kappa_{k}\right), where u​(κk)𝑢subscript𝜅𝑘u\left(\kappa_{k}\right) is given by u​(κk)=exp⁡{j​2​π​ζ​sin⁡(κk)}𝑢subscript𝜅𝑘𝑗2𝜋𝜁subscript𝜅𝑘u\left(\kappa_{k}\right)=\exp\{j2\pi\zeta\sin(\kappa_{k})\} with κksubscript𝜅𝑘\kappa_{k} being the angle of arrival (AoA) at the PS from the k𝑘k-th device, and ζ𝜁\zeta being the distance between two neighboring antenna elements. Furthermore, ξn,m(k)​(κk)superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑛𝑚𝑘subscript𝜅𝑘\xi_{n,m}^{(k)}\left(\kappa_{k}\right) is the angular spread of the AoA at the PS from device k𝑘k given by ξn,m(k)​(κk)=exp⁡{−2​ϑk2​[π​(n−m)​d​cos⁡(κk)]2}superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑛𝑚𝑘subscript𝜅𝑘2superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϑ𝑘2superscriptdelimited-[]𝜋𝑛𝑚𝑑subscript𝜅𝑘2\xi_{n,m}^{(k)}\left(\kappa_{k}\right)=\exp\left\{-2\vartheta_{k}^{2}[\pi\left(n-m\right)d\cos\left(\kappa_{k}\right)]^{2}\right\}. Here, ϑksubscriptitalic-ϑ𝑘\vartheta_{k} is the standard deviation of the angular spread at device k𝑘k and is chosen uniformly and randomly in the interval of [12,15]1215\left[12,15\right] throughout the simulations. The nominal values of AoAs are further calculated geometrically from the position of the devices. For the sake of comparison, we evaluate the performance for three baselines in addition to the proposed algorithms:

  • •

    Random Policy: An OTA-FL scheme in which a subset of L𝐿L antennas at the PS are selected randomly. In the random policy, based on the subset of selected antennas, the receive beamforming and transmit coefficients are optimized by AO algorithm.

  • •

    Greedy Antenna Selection Policy: A scheme that selects the subset of L𝐿L antennas at the PS which corresponds to the L𝐿L strongest sum of channel gains, i.e., the L𝐿L antennas with L𝐿L largest ∑k=1K|hk,n|2superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑛2\displaystyle\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left|h_{k,n}\right|^{2} for n∈{1,…,N}𝑛1…𝑁n\in\left\{1,\ldots,N\right\}. Similar to the random policy, we optimize the receive beamforming and transmit coefficients by AO algorithm.

  • •

    All Antenna Selection: An OTA-FL scheme in which all the antennas at the PS are selected with the assumption that the RF chains are available for all of them. The receive beamforming and transmit coefficients are optimized alternatively.

VII-B Local Training Model Settings

We consider 10-class image classification over CIFAR-10 [41] and FMNIST [42] datasets. The dataset CIFAR-10 contains 101010 classes of color images with 600060006000 images per class. Each class is divided into 500050005000 images for training and the remaining 100010001000 images are used for testing. The dataset FMNIST (Fashion-MNIST) has 101010 classes of gray-scale cloth images. There are 60,0006000060,000 training images and 10,0001000010,000 test images. To address the classification task, we train a convolutional neural network (CNN). For CIFAR-10 dataset, we train a CNN with the widely-known VGG13 network 19 [43]. The network consists of eight convolutional layers and two subsequent fully-connected layers. Each max-pooling layer is followed by a convolutional layer. The network is trained to minimize the empirical cross-entropy loss function in an OTA-FL manner by utilizing SGD with momentum algorithm. The CNN model for FMNIST dataset comprises three convolutional layers, one fully-connected layer and a classification layer with softmax function. We consider two data distribution scenarios:

  1. 1.

    i.i.d data distribution in which the overall training and testing datasets are shuffled randomly and partitioned equally and evenly among the devices.

  2. 2.

    Non-i.i.d distribution with label skew in which datasets are split with heterogeneous label distributions. Specifically, at each device, two labels are chosen at random. Then, 60% of the datapoints in the client’s dataset are chosen to be of those two labels and the remaining 40% datapoints are chosen uniformly from the other labels.

We set the total number of communication rounds to be T=5×10=50𝑇51050T=5\times 10=50 where channel varies after every few communication rounds.

VII-C Simulation Results

VII-C1 Impact of Antenna Selection on Aggregation Error

We start our simulations by investigating the impact of antenna selection on aggregation error. Fig. 1 shows the aggregation error against SNR, defined as P/σ2𝑃superscript𝜎2P/\sigma^{2} for L=16𝐿16L=16 and L=64𝐿64L=64. As expected, the figure shows that the error reduces with the increase in SNR.

It is further seen in the figure that the FISTA closely tracks the Lasso-based algorithm. This is expected, as both the algorithms select the antennas based on ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1}-norm minimization. The close match of both algorithms further indicates that the extra tuning and computational complexity of the Lasso-based scheme does not gain that much in terms of performance and that the FISTA scheme is a good approximation for ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1}-norm minimization problem. Comparing the cases of L=16𝐿16L=16 and L=64𝐿64L=64, it is further seen that the Lasso-based and FISTA algorithms outperform the PDD scheme for L≪Nmuch-less-than𝐿𝑁L\ll N; whereas, the PDD scheme starts to be superior as L𝐿L increases substantially. This follows from the fact that both the Lasso-based and FISTA inherently work based on the ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1}-norm approximation of optimal sparsity recovery that is known to perform close to optimal for considerably sparse signals, i.e., L≪Nmuch-less-than𝐿𝑁L\ll N. For large choices of L𝐿L, the selection matrix is not significantly sparse anymore, and thus the sparse-recovery-based strategies perform poorly as compared to the PDD scheme. It is further observed in both the figures that as the number of selected antennas increases, the gap between different approaches shrinks. This is expected as in the extreme case of L=N𝐿𝑁L=N all algorithms perform the same.

VII-C2 Independent vs Correlated Channel Fading

In Fig.2, we investigate the impact of the number of selected antennas on the aggregation error. It is observed that the aggregation error decreases for all the schemes as the number of selected antennas (or equivalently the number of RF chains) increases. This is the direct result of the fact that with large active beams at the PS, any desired combination of the signals can be readily calculated over the air, and hence the interference among the devices can be avoided. Despite this behavior, the figure indicates that a reasonable aggregation error is achievable by utilizing even less than 50%percent5050\% of the available antennas at the PS. Fig.2 shows the same behavior as the one seen in Fig. 1. For sake of comparison, we have further plotted the figure for both the standard Rayleigh fading (Fig. 2(a)) and the correlated Rayleigh fading (Fig. 2(b)) specified by the correlation model described in Section VII-A. From the figure, we can see a slight improvement with the idealistic standard Rayleigh model. This difference is however considerably slight, as our proposed schemes compensate for the channel impact via proper beamforming and power scaling.

VII-C3 Testing Accuracy

In Fig. 3, the testing accuracy for the training of the CNN over the homogeneous network (i.i.d. data distribution) with FMNIST dataset is plotted against the number of communication rounds. The observed behaviors in Figs. 1 and 2 are further seen in this figure: the proposed schemes outperform the baselines. With a small number of active antennas, Lasso and FISTA perform the best, while for larger values of L𝐿L, PDD shows the best performance. The results further show that the testing accuracy of all-antenna selection policy can be achieved by the proposed scheme, with even less than 50%percent5050\% of antennas being active. This result indicates that with a proper antenna selection strategy, a desired learning performance can be achieved in the network at a considerably lower implementation cost.

VII-C4 Heterogeneous Data Sets

The results for a heterogeneous network (non-i.i.d. data distribution) is further shown in Fig. 4. The figure reports the same observation with smaller gap among different schemes which is, due to the data heterogeneity. We finally show the results for the CIFAR-10 dataset with both i.i.d and non-i.i.d distributions in Fig. 5, considering the case with L=64𝐿64L=64 active antennas. As the figure depicts, unlike the baseline schemes, the proposed schemes show higher robustness against data heterogeneity. This follows the fact that the proposed schemes take both the learning and communication aspects into account.

VIII Conclusions

This paper studied joint communication and aggregation design for OTA-FL in massive MIMO systems with reduced RF complexity. Our design invoked the AS scheme to reduce the implementational cost and complexity. We addressed the joint design problem by developing three algorithms based on the PDD, Lasso and soft-thresholding methods, catering to a variety of network scenarios with different computational complexity requirements. Our investigations demonstrate that the algorithms based on Lasso and soft-thresholding perform closely with a minor performance-complexity trade-off: the Lasso-type algorithm slightly outperforms the soft-thresholding approach, while the latter requires less efforts for tuning and thus has lower complexity. This behavior was expected, since both approaches select antennas via ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1}-norm sparse recovery. The PDD-based algorithm however performs differently as compared to the sparse-recovery-based techniques. When the number of active antennas is small, the Lasso-type and soft-thresholding-based algorithms outperform the PDD-based approach. Nevertheless, as the number of active antennas increases, the PDD-based approach starts to perform superior. This observation follows the fact that both the Lasso-type and soft-thresholding-based algorithms are sparse recovery techniques which perform well at high sparsity, i.e., extremely lower number of active antennas as compared to the PS array size. Comparing our results (with only a few active antennas) with the all antenna selection scenario (with all the antennas active), we found that the achievable testing accuracy closely tracks the all antenna selection performance. This indicates the effectiveness of AS-based massive MIMO transmission for OTA-FL.

Appendix A Proof of Theorem 1

We start the proof by considering a selection vector 𝐬𝐬\mathbf{s} whose ℓ0subscriptℓ0\ell_{0}-norm reads ‖𝐬‖0<Lsubscriptnorm𝐬0𝐿\left\|\mathbf{s}\right\|_{0}<L. Let ℓℓ\ell be an index out of the support of 𝐬𝐬\mathbf{s}. This means that sℓ=0subscript𝑠ℓ0s_{\ell}=0. We now construct a new selection vector 𝐬^^𝐬\hat{\mathbf{s}} as 𝐬^=𝐬+𝐞ℓ^𝐬𝐬subscript𝐞ℓ\hat{\mathbf{s}}=\mathbf{s}+{\mathbf{e}}_{\ell}, where 𝐞ℓsubscript𝐞ℓ{\mathbf{e}}_{\ell} denotes the one-hot vector of length N𝑁N with the non-zero entry at index ℓℓ\ell, i.e., eℓ=1subscripteℓ1\mathrm{e}_{\ell}=1 and ej=0subscripte𝑗0\mathrm{e}_{j}=0 for j≠ℓ𝑗ℓj\neq\ell. For this selection, the aggregation error reads

ϵ​(𝐦,𝐬^,𝐁)italic-ϵ𝐦^𝐬𝐁\displaystyle\epsilon\left({\mathbf{m}},\hat{\mathbf{s}},\mathbf{B}\right) =‖𝐦𝖧​Diag​{𝐬^}​𝐇𝐁−ϕ𝖧‖2+σ2​‖𝐦𝖧​Diag​{𝐬^}‖2absentsuperscriptnormsuperscript𝐦𝖧Diag^𝐬𝐇𝐁superscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝖧2superscript𝜎2superscriptnormsuperscript𝐦𝖧Diag^𝐬2\displaystyle=\|{\mathbf{m}}^{\mathsf{H}}\mathrm{Diag}\left\{\hat{\mathbf{s}}\right\}\mathbf{H}\mathbf{B}-\bm{\phi}^{\mathsf{H}}\|^{2}+\sigma^{2}\|{\mathbf{m}}^{\mathsf{H}}\mathrm{Diag}\left\{\hat{\mathbf{s}}\right\}\|^{2} (51a)
=‖𝐦𝖧​𝐒𝐇𝐁−ϕ𝖧+mℓ∗​𝐚ℓ𝖳‖2+σ2​(‖𝐦𝖧​𝐒‖2+|mℓ|2),absentsuperscriptnormsuperscript𝐦𝖧𝐒𝐇𝐁superscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝖧superscriptsubscript𝑚ℓsubscriptsuperscript𝐚𝖳ℓ2superscript𝜎2superscriptnormsuperscript𝐦𝖧𝐒2superscriptsubscript𝑚ℓ2\displaystyle=\|{\mathbf{m}}^{\mathsf{H}}\mathbf{S}\mathbf{H}\mathbf{B}-\bm{\phi}^{\mathsf{H}}+m_{\ell}^{*}{\mathbf{a}}^{\mathsf{T}}_{\ell}\|^{2}+\sigma^{2}\left(\|{\mathbf{m}}^{\mathsf{H}}\mathbf{S}\|^{2}+\left|m_{\ell}\right|^{2}\right), (51b)

where 𝐒=Diag​{𝐬}𝐒Diag𝐬\mathbf{S}=\mathrm{Diag}\left\{\mathbf{s}\right\} and 𝐚ℓ𝖳superscriptsubscript𝐚ℓ𝖳{\mathbf{a}}_{\ell}^{\mathsf{T}} denotes the ℓℓ\ell-th row of 𝐇𝐁𝐇𝐁\mathbf{H}\mathbf{B}. We now construct the receiver vector 𝐦¯¯𝐦\bar{{\mathbf{m}}} from 𝐦𝐦{\mathbf{m}} by setting its entry ℓℓ\ell to zero, i.e., m¯ℓ=0subscript¯𝑚ℓ0\bar{m}_{\ell}=0 and m¯n=mnsubscript¯𝑚𝑛subscript𝑚𝑛\bar{m}_{n}=m_{n} for n≠ℓ𝑛ℓn\neq\ell. Noting that sℓ=0subscript𝑠ℓ0s_{\ell}=0, we can conclude that 𝐦𝖧​𝐒=𝐦¯𝖧​𝐒superscript𝐦𝖧𝐒superscript¯𝐦𝖧𝐒{\mathbf{m}}^{\mathsf{H}}\mathbf{S}=\bar{{\mathbf{m}}}^{\mathsf{H}}\mathbf{S}, and thus

ϵ​(𝐦,𝐬^,𝐁)italic-ϵ𝐦^𝐬𝐁\displaystyle\epsilon\left({\mathbf{m}},\hat{\mathbf{s}},\mathbf{B}\right) =‖𝐦¯𝖧​𝐒𝐇𝐁−ϕ𝖧+mℓ∗​𝐚ℓ𝖳‖2+σ2​(‖𝐦¯𝖧​𝐒‖2+|mℓ|2)absentsuperscriptnormsuperscript¯𝐦𝖧𝐒𝐇𝐁superscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝖧superscriptsubscript𝑚ℓsubscriptsuperscript𝐚𝖳ℓ2superscript𝜎2superscriptnormsuperscript¯𝐦𝖧𝐒2superscriptsubscript𝑚ℓ2\displaystyle=\|\bar{{\mathbf{m}}}^{\mathsf{H}}\mathbf{S}\mathbf{H}\mathbf{B}-\bm{\phi}^{\mathsf{H}}+m_{\ell}^{*}{\mathbf{a}}^{\mathsf{T}}_{\ell}\|^{2}+\sigma^{2}\left(\|\bar{{\mathbf{m}}}^{\mathsf{H}}\mathbf{S}\|^{2}+\left|m_{\ell}\right|^{2}\right) (52a)

ϵ​(𝐦,𝐬,𝐁)=ϵ¯​(𝐦¯,0,𝐬^,𝐁).italic-ϵ𝐦𝐬𝐁¯italic-ϵ¯𝐦0^𝐬𝐁\displaystyle\epsilon\left({\mathbf{m}},{\mathbf{s}},\mathbf{B}\right)=\bar{\epsilon}\left(\bar{{\mathbf{m}}},0,\hat{\mathbf{s}},\mathbf{B}\right). (53)

For the vector 𝐬^^𝐬\hat{\mathbf{s}}, the minimum aggregation error subject to the transmit power is given by

min𝐦¯,𝐁⁡minmℓ⁡ϵ¯​(𝐦¯,mℓ,𝐬^,𝐁)subscript¯𝐦𝐁subscriptsubscript𝑚ℓ¯italic-ϵ¯𝐦subscript𝑚ℓ^𝐬𝐁\displaystyle\min_{\bar{{\mathbf{m}}},\mathbf{B}}\min_{m_{\ell}}\bar{\epsilon}\left(\bar{{\mathbf{m}}},m_{\ell},\hat{\mathbf{s}},\mathbf{B}\right) (𝒬1subscript𝒬1\mathcal{Q}_{1})
s.t.C:|bk|2<P​ for ​k∈[K].\displaystyle{\rm{s.t.}}\quad\begin{array}[]{l}C:\left|b_{k}\right|^{2}<P\text{ for }k\in\left[K\right].\end{array} (55)

The inner minimization is a standard quadratic optimization; therefore, we can conclude that if ‖𝐦¯𝖧​𝐒𝐇𝐁−ϕ𝖧‖∞≠0subscriptnormsuperscript¯𝐦𝖧𝐒𝐇𝐁superscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝖧0\left\|\bar{{\mathbf{m}}}^{\mathsf{H}}\mathbf{S}\mathbf{H}\mathbf{B}-\bm{\phi}^{\mathsf{H}}\right\|_{\infty}\neq 0 then the minimizer, i.e., mℓ⋆=argminmℓϵ¯​(𝐦¯,mℓ,𝐬^,𝐁)superscriptsubscript𝑚ℓ⋆subscriptargminsubscript𝑚ℓ¯italic-ϵ¯𝐦subscript𝑚ℓ^𝐬𝐁m_{\ell}^{\star}=\operatorname*{argmin}_{m_{\ell}}\bar{\epsilon}\left(\bar{{\mathbf{m}}},m_{\ell},\hat{\mathbf{s}},\mathbf{B}\right) is non zero. This means that minmℓ⁡ϵ¯​(𝐦¯,mℓ,𝐬^,𝐁)<ϵ¯​(𝐦¯,0,𝐬^,𝐁),subscriptsubscript𝑚ℓ¯italic-ϵ¯𝐦subscript𝑚ℓ^𝐬𝐁¯italic-ϵ¯𝐦0^𝐬𝐁\min_{m_{\ell}}\bar{\epsilon}\left(\bar{{\mathbf{m}}},m_{\ell},\hat{\mathbf{s}},\mathbf{B}\right)<\bar{\epsilon}\left(\bar{{\mathbf{m}}},0,\hat{\mathbf{s}},\mathbf{B}\right), for a given pair (𝐦¯,𝐁)¯𝐦𝐁\left(\bar{{\mathbf{m}}},\mathbf{B}\right). Hence, we have

min𝐦,𝐁⁡ϵ​(𝐦,𝐬^,𝐁)​ s.t. ​C<min𝐦,𝐁⁡ϵ​(𝐦,𝐬,𝐁)​ s.t. ​Csubscript𝐦𝐁italic-ϵ𝐦^𝐬𝐁 s.t. 𝐶subscript𝐦𝐁italic-ϵ𝐦𝐬𝐁 s.t. 𝐶\displaystyle\min_{{\mathbf{m}},\mathbf{B}}\epsilon\left({\mathbf{m}},\hat{\mathbf{s}},\mathbf{B}\right)\;\text{ s.t. }C<\min_{{\mathbf{m}},\mathbf{B}}\epsilon\left({\mathbf{m}},{\mathbf{s}},\mathbf{B}\right)\;\text{ s.t. }C (56)

with C𝐶C referring to the constraint in 𝒬1subscript𝒬1\mathcal{Q}_{1}. The inequality in (56) indicates that given the constraint in ‖𝐦¯𝖧​𝐒𝐇𝐁−ϕ𝖧‖∞≠0subscriptnormsuperscript¯𝐦𝖧𝐒𝐇𝐁superscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝖧0\left\|\bar{{\mathbf{m}}}^{\mathsf{H}}\mathbf{S}\mathbf{H}\mathbf{B}-\bm{\phi}^{\mathsf{H}}\right\|_{\infty}\neq 0, by setting an entry of the selection vector to zero the objective function in 𝒫4subscript𝒫4{\mathcal{P}}_{4} always increases. Hence, the solution of 𝒫4subscript𝒫4{\mathcal{P}}_{4} satisfies ‖𝐬‖0=Lsubscriptnorm𝐬0𝐿\left\|\mathbf{s}\right\|_{0}=L. This concludes the proof.
